TIME LAPSE- EXT. FAITHS' CAMP- DAWN

TIME LAPSE- EXT. BIRCH FOREST- PRE-DAWN

EXT. NORTHERN PLAINS / FOREST EDGE- DAY
TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS CAMP- NIGHT
TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS, HUNKPAPA TRAIL- DUSK
AT THE FRONT OF THE GROUP
TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS GULCH- NIGHT
TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MARYANNE STEWART is twenty-two, she has a plain beauty to her, freckles, hair gathered in a bun. Her face is underl by the candle she uses to heat a needle. She’s holding th hand of her LITTLE BROTHER, age 6, about to remove a spli from his finger. She blows on the needle to cool it.

dialogues.speaker: MARYANNE
dialogues.text: A splinter already hurts more than pulling it out. Little Brother tries to be brave, but he’s nervous. Pinne to her dress at Maryanne’s throat is a silver BROOCH, an intricate Celtic pattern interwoven with a yellow ribbon. In the small, rough-hewn cabin behind her, we see Maryann heavy-set BIG BROTHER (27), LITTLE SISTER (10), and MOTHE (50’s.) They’re settling for the night, cleaning the dinn dishes, getting the kids into their nightshirts, etc.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER SISTER
dialogues.text: I’m not sleepy.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: We’ll story you to bed. (to Maryanne-) You need to take your rest, too, Mary. F’you wanna look pretty when your Dutchman comes courtin’ tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: MARYANNE
dialogues.text: You hush. Maryanne smiles, lowers the needle towards her brother's finger...

dialogues.speaker: BIG BROTHER
dialogues.text: He told daddy he was saving wages for his own settlement. Little Brother squirms, watching the needle approach.

dialogues.speaker: MARYANNE
dialogues.text: I only just met him. He ain’t... The pin-point approaches young skin... CRACK, CRACK, CRACK, rapid rifle fire sounds from outsid The whole family’s attention snaps towards the sound. The freeze for a moment, spooked like animals. Big Brother moves first, cracks the shutter on a window. silvery moonlight, we catch a glimpse of waving prairie grass, MUZZLE-FLASHES with the CRACKS of rifle fire. There’s a FIGURE, running, fast approaching the house. Maryanne sticks the needle in the candle and puts a protective arm around Little Brother. Little Sister nuzzl into her mother’s arms, frightened.

dialogues.speaker: LITTLE SISTER
dialogues.text: Mom...? BAM, everybody jumps when he hits the door, yanking it op moment later to reveal Maryanne’s heavy FATHER (50’s.) He breathless, terrified, a rifle in his hand. CRACK, CRACK, distant rifle-fire continues from the cabin behind him.

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: What’s happening?

dialogues.speaker: FATHER, (BREATHLESS)
dialogues.text: They were in the Williams’ house.

dialogues.speaker: BIG BROTHER
dialogues.text: Indians? Big Brother grabs a rifle off the wall, steps towards his father, who puts a hand on his shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: FATHER
dialogues.text: Stay with the women. Down, into the root cellar. Get.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The settlement is two small clapboard homes alone in an o of grass stirred by heavy winds. From the Stewart House, see Maryanne and her family hurrying out of the back door down into a cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Her father ushers Maryanne down the stairs, where her mot and sisters wait with a lantern. Her brother follows afte a rifle in hand. Father lifts the doors above-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep your lamp low and this door locked. You don’t open it no matter what. You hear? Brother nods as he shuts the door.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER SISTER
dialogues.text: Dad!

dialogues.speaker: BROTHER
dialogues.text: Quiet.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER SISTER, (PANICKING)
dialogues.text: Mom, mom...

dialogues.speaker: MOTHER
dialogues.text: You mind your brother. Hush. Big Brother latches the storm doors shut and backs into t middle of the cellar. He takes the lamp from his mother a turns the flame down low. We hear muffled SHOUTS above, movement. The little childr in their white nightshirts are crying, holding onto their mother. The adults all look up at the underside of the floorboards, eyes glassy with fear. Maryanne shakes her head at her Little Brother’s tears an wipes at his cheek. In a whisper, barely more than silenc

dialogues.speaker: MARYANNE
dialogues.text: Don’t cry. Be brave for me. She holds his gaze until he takes a breath, and nods. The cellar around them is cluttered, filled with burlap s of grain, half-mended farm tools. Lamplight throws weavin shadows on the walls around them. CRACK, CRACK, more rifle shots, and then a man’s SCREAM. Maryanne puts a hand to her mouth. Brother tightens his f on the rifle. Mother holds the two crying children. Relative SILENCE above. The family stands frozen, trying to breathe. Little Brother SNIFFS and all heads snap towa the sound. Mother puts a gentle hand over his mouth, plea with her eyes for quiet. Something DRAGS over the floorboards above. The family lo upwards, terrified. SCCCCRRRRT, the dragging sounds like carpet knife over the rough boards.  BOOM, a muffled shotgun blast. Then BOOM, another. The family all look upwards, from the dragging sound to- BOOM third blast, and a fourth. All of the adults fail to notice what both of the crying children see- a silhouetted FIGURE in the shadows behind Brother, low to the ground, moving in. Little Brother and Sister draw tiny breaths, eyes fixed o the figure, almost too terrified to speak.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNGER SISTER, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: «..mom. Her mother shushes her. The DRAGGING above has stopped. Subtly, a dinner plate-sized circle of dirt by Little Bro begins to move. He feels it through his socked foot and looks. Eight inches of soil shake like simmering water. Little Brother looks at his mom, who stares upwards at th floorboards. He looks back down. Dirt moves outward from the center of the circle. SOMETHING PALE begins to surfac like a boiled worm, or the finger of a drowned child... Maryanne, Big Brother, and Mother all stare upwards... Little Brother looks down at the dirt and inhales to scre Little Sister looks away from the figure slinking towards Brother and closes her eyes, crying, terrified. An agonizing moment before- Big Brother SCREAMS and the lantern drops. Maryanne spins. The lantern hits the ground at her brothe feet and shatters, the momentary flash of firelight revea him clawing at the dirt floor as he’s pulled violently ba into the shadows... The light extinguishes, leaving pitch darkness. Little Sister SCREAMS. We hear YELLING. SCREAMS. VIOLENCE. Then sudden quiet. There are inhuman RATTLES and PURRS, the sounds of bodies dragged over the ground. Soil shifts. SILENCE. BLACK ON SCREEN.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Dakota Territories August 15th, 1879 DRIPPING. Flies BUZZ. A vertical line of light grows into the rectangle of an opening door, silhouetting a FIGURE in a derby and duster against the lush, slowly waving grass of the Dakota plain

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE WILLIAMS HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: The figure moves into the absolute black of the house, st contrast against the big sky glare of the Badlands. He pu the derby from his head. Hundreds of specks of darkness, FLIES, rise in a cloud an swarm the lighted rectangle of the doorway. The man, little more than a dark shape in the sliver of light, is DUTCH, a heavily-accented Belgian immigrant two years off the boat. Dutch is sharp, capable but out of place, a little anxious in the West.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (ACCENTED)
dialogues.text: -..Is anybody home? Mr. Williams? The Stewarts are... The pupil in the illuminated crescent of Dutch's face wid adjusting to the dark, then narrows.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Jesus god. Dutch backs away, his boots sliding through a rich, crims puddle, never taking his eyes off the thing before him. At the door he puts his hand against the jamb, steadying himself. There's something small and smooth under his pal He takes his hand away and looks. A TOOTH, a molar, lodge in the wood as if fired there. Dutch stumbles out and...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK SETTLEMENT- DAY
dialogues.text: -..onto the porch, nauseated, his blood-stained boots los purchase on the friction-smoothed boards. He flails and falls into JOHN CLAY. The enormous man catches Dutch. Clay is a mountain, early 40's, easily 6 feet and 250 lbs. of John Wayne.  All-business all the time, he’s a commanding presence, strong, an obvious leader. He's holding a black-and-white PHOTOGRAPH in a broken frame in one of his enormous hands

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Basement’s empty. The Stewarts are gone. Maryanne say anything to you about leaving? Dutch shakes his head, no. Clay presses the Stewart famil portrait into Dutch's hands and pushes him off the porch.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: What about the Williams? Dutch shakes his head and points into the dark doorway be them. Clay turns and steps into the Williams' House, vanishing into the darkness. We see the settlement in daylight, the two clapboard home bleached gray from hard weather. The surrounding grass sw We get a better look at Dutch: late 20’s, lean, angular. body language reads somewhere between Ichabod Crane and Sherlock, contained nervous energy and remarkably sharp e Dutch looks at the photograph Clay gave him. The Stewarts are a large family, posed before their home on the Washbu Crick. The children’s images are blurred, they moved duri the exposure. Dutch scans the faces, focusing in on Maryanne. He touches her image, smearing blood on the pic by mistake. He grimaces and wipes it clean with his sleev The TWO HORSES tied to the fence behind Dutch lift their and roll their eyes, nervous. Clay emerges from the door, carrying Dutch's Derby as if were a pair of discarded panties. Dutch takes the hat; there's a crimson stain on the crown. Clay walks to his horse and leans his hands on the saddle staring out at the slowly waving grass.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Indians. God help them.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We have to get them back. Clay nods, just barely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: DOBIE SPACKS walks through the grass, looking down, lost rumination. He pinches at his upper lip, trying to tweeze between his thumb and finger the fine down growing there. Dobie will soon be 16. He carries a pitcher of milk. Behi him, the Spacks House sits large, whitewashed, and Victor like some Edward Hopper sentinel. Ahead, WILLIAM PARCHER follows Dobie's mother towards a thick, twisted box elder tree growing on a rise in the la Parcher is a mischievous-looking rancher in his 50's, a moustache, glorious sideburns. Parcher carries a picnic basket. He hangs back and whispe conspiratorially to Dobie-

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I hemped three men on yonder tree.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Indians, anyway. Hanged 'em dead. Parcher winks at Dobie, showing off. The boy smiles, he’s impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Don't feed my boy your horse-shit, Mr. Parcher. GERTRUDE SPACKS, carrying a quilt, looks back at them. Sh in her early 50's, attractive, rich.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That ain't horse-shit, that's history. Boy ought to learn where we come from. They arrive under the tree and Gertrude spreads the quilt

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Mind the cursing in front of my boy. They sit and Parcher begins to take food from the basket. Dobie looks up at the sun through the gnarled branches of elder. We hear the CREAK of twisting ropes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great god amighty, is that coconut? Parcher pulls a cake from the picnic basket.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Mom got it special.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: I baked it. The coconut came from back East. Parcher looks at the cake, then at Gertrude.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Ten years back, not a mile from here, I had to eat horse to survive. Dobie is impressed.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: That's disgusting.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: It wasn't my horse. Point is, we're here now eating coconut cake. Right civilized country. Parcher cuts himself a slice that encompasses nearly a quarter of the cake.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: We have chicken and cornbread.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I know it. I'll attend to that cornbread directly. Parcher takes an enormous bite of cake, smearing his moustache with icing.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: There's a rider. Dobie points. Parcher gets to his feet and squints. A MAN ON A HORSE gallops towards them, half a mile away.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Listen, cowboy, how ‘bout taking your mother in the house.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got a funny hat. I think it's your ranch-hand, Mr. Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Anybody can wear a funny hat and that ain't Sunday riding. Take your mother inside.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Let's go, Dobie. Parcher SNAPS the cover guard off of his revolver. Dobie turns and looks. Parcher sees the boy eyeing the gun and grins a little bit.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Go on. Dobie and Gertrude hurry toward the house. Parcher, icing smeared on his moustache, squints into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DAKOTA BADLANDS- DAY
dialogues.text: We reveal the rider: Dutch. He drives his horse through t knee-high grass towards Parcher, a half-mile distant.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SPACKS HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch rears his frothing horse to a halt in the shade of box elder and dismounts a few feet from parcher. Dobie an Gertrude are specks in the grass halfway back to the Hous

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Dutch, god damnit, I was having a picnic.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (BREATHLESS)
dialogues.text: Indians. They killed... Here. Dutch fishes a many-folded square of paper from his pocke and hands it to Parcher. Scrawled in grease pencil- “INDIAN MASSACRE AT WASHBURNER CRICK. WILLIAMS FAMILY DEA STEWART FAMILY KIDNAPPED, 6 MISSING. FETCHING HENRY V.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It's from Mr. Clay. They took Maryanne... her whole family...  10.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I can read. Jesus. Indians kill them little Williams girls, too?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yes... no. Mr. Williams did. And then, what is the word... Dutch pantomimes shooting himself in the mouth.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Suicide. Dutch points at Parcher, exactly.

dialogues.speaker: INT. GERTRUDE'S PARLOR- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch thirstily drains a glass of water, jams his derby b onto his head. The parlor is sparse, Victorian, dusty.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...If we're dealing with Crow or Ute, Dobie could see things a boy shouldn't have to. Parcher perches on a stool, pulling on his boots. Gertrud watches Dobie tie provision onto two horses outside.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: I've made up my mind, Will.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You've already lost a man to the Indians, I don't want to take another.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: I don't have a man in this house, I've got a boy. You take him to Washburne Crick and bring him back and maybe I'll have two. Parcher's pleased with this. Gertrude turns to Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Would you like more water? Dutch shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We have to go.  11. Dobie enters from the front porch, dressed in brand-new riding clothes. He's Christmas-morning excited.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: The horses are ready.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Then let's get to it. Gertrude takes Dobie's head, kisses his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Be good. Mr. Parcher’s lived through everything this country could throw at him. You stay close and mind him, and you'll be fine. (then, to Parcher-) And you, too. She kisses him lightly on the cheek. Parcher mugs pleased shock before leaning to kiss her back. She shoves him off

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: When you get back.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Yes, ma'am. Parcher and Dobie eye each other significantly, both happ and uncomfortable. Dutch puts down his empty water glass.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch stands in the open doorway of the empty Stewart hou looking in. The Williams house is open behind him, no sig of Parcher or Dobie. Dutch walks around the house and notices a SHADOW on the edge of the settlement, past the barn, a dark circle in the grass. He walks over to it. A CIRCULAR DEPRESSION about four feet across, the grass pushed aside and collapsed, the earth beneath it churned. Hundreds of ANTS crawl around in the soil. Dutch crouches and presses his fingers into the circle. T sink easily into the dirt.

dialogues.speaker: INT. THE WILLIAMS HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: In the dimmed light, Parcher and Dobie cover their mouths with dust cloths. Out of focus, DEEP CRIMSON stains the w and ceiling behind them. Parcher crouches over MRS. WILLI

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A matronly corpse, shotgunned. The neck and chest are rou buckshot-torn, her arm nearly separated. There's very lit blood, just the raspberry chew of the wound.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: She should have bled out more. Same with the girls.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Ida and Daphne... I think those where their names. Dobie can't help but glance through the doorway into the girls' bedroom where lie- The TWO DEAD WILLIAMS GIRLS. Small nightshirt-clad bodies twisted in sheets torn and singed by buckshot. Remarkably little blood. Child flesh chewed like ground chuck. Dobie is close to retching. These are far from the first corpse Parcher’s seen. Any concern he shows is for Dobie, almost like a kind uncle.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You want to wait outside?

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Good. I wonder... Parcher looks at a GASH in Mrs. Williams' neck, a good ei inches above any shotgun damage. It's about an inch acros and six inches long. It sinks over half an inch into her neck, but doesn't appear to have bled.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: What kind of weapon makes a wound like that? A chisel? Some kind of wood plane? As he talks, Dobie turns and looks at the source of all t crimson behind them. MR. WILLIAMS' HEADLESS CORPSE on the rough floorboards by fireplace, the shotgun he used to decapitate himself lyin between his curled hands. And BLOOD. Unlike his wife and girls, there was no shorta of the stuff inside Dad. It marks the wall and ceiling behind him, Jackson-Pollock style. Dobie stares at the twin barrel of the bloody shotgun.  13.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: That gun only fires twice. (Parcher waits for him) ...-He would have had to reload. To kill everybody.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...If it was Appaches or Crow, any Christian woman would prefer dying to capture. If Mr. Williams had time to reload, it's because his wife gave it to him. Dobie looks at the ground.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: If it came to that, I hope you'd be strong enough to take care of your mother. Dobie stares into the bedroom, at the little girls’ corps

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Alright.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Our pity belongs to the Stewart family, they're still alive and captive...

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (0.S., INTERRUPTING)
dialogues.text: Mr. Parcher! Mr. Clay's coming!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK, YARD- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch stares to the horizon. TWO DOZEN RIDERS approach. Parcher and Dobie emerge from the Williams house. Parcher uncorks some whisky and squints at the approaching riders

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: He find Henry Victor?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yeah, and near thirty bluecoats.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Mighty Christ. That cock-sure little shit’s brought the whole fort. Dutch sees Dobie, his eyes red-rimmed and glassy. Dutch touches the boy's shoulder.  14.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You alright?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Get off the boy, he's fine. Dutch withdraws his hand. Parcher drinks some whisky.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I found something.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK, BEHIND THE BARN- DAY
dialogues.text: Parcher, crouching before the circle, sinks his hand into softened earth up to his wrist. Dutch and Dobie hover beh him. The two dozen RIDERS approach in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I s'pose... a wallowing buffalo coulda done this. He smells the dirt on his finger. Clay, at the head of the dozen riders, reigns his horse t stop a few yards behind Parcher. HENRY VICTOR stops his own horse beside him. He’s 40 year old, a thin, tall dandy with a doughboy face and sharp, arrogant eyes; the spoiled child of a Texan war hero. He wears military blue and Lieutenant's stripes.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Looks like you found yourself a hole in the ground, Will. There’s an old rivalry between them. Parcher stands to fa the mounted men as a half dozen of H.V.'s BLUECOATS arriv behind them. Parcher grins at the insult, brushing the an from his hand.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That and four corpses. And six missing. Most of those being women and children.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I’ll get the horses. Dutch starts back towards the yard, H.V. stops him.  15.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Hold up now. This is my command, I gotta know who we’re hunting. How long have the Indians had them? Clay looks annoyed at H.V.’s obvious, arrogant pleasure a exercising authority. The Bluecoats behind him are soldiers, between the ages o and 30. Other Bluecoats ride into the settlement below.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Near a day now.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: That's more than long enough for those women to’ve been... Dobie looks at Parcher, long enough for what? Dutch looks sick with H.V.’s implication.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We should go. The longer we wait-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: You want to go face an Indian war party on your lonesome? Dutch clenches his fists, looks to Clay for support. Clay shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: You go off alone, those blanket heads will peel you like an orange.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Maryanne is lukewarm on you with your skin on, Dutch. Follow along, we'll do this thing right.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR, (TO PARCHER)
dialogues.text: You think it's the Sioux?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'd incline to guess Apache or Commanche. Got a family suicide, leads me believe the tribe'd have a right smart reputation for torture.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: The Sioux understand torture.  16. His intonation almost sounds like a cruel, inappropriate joke. At any rate, a few of the Bluecoats SNICKER.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK, YARD- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch, Parcher, and Clay stride quickly across the yard, leading H.V. towards the Williams house. Dutch eyes the approaching open door warily, a little sic It's so quiet that we can just hear the FLIES inside. They pass a young black man leaning against the Williams' house porch railing, "WALNUT" CALLAGHAN, (late 20's.) Callaghan wears a worn bluecoat jacket, but the rest of h clothes are catch-as-catch-can. Dutch slows, he's not happy to be walking back into a slaughterhouse. Parcher, Clay, and H.V. pass the BLUECOAT LIEUTENANT stan watch at the door and enter the Williams' house. Dutch lingers on the porch. H.V. looks back at him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Your Occidental isn't coming in? Dutch shakes his head, close to puking. H.V. smirks and l the door shut. Dutch walks back out into the dirt patch and puts his han on his knees. The nausea passes and he spits, looks out a the horizon. Callaghan sits nearby.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You alright, man?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (SHAKING HIS HEAD)
dialogues.text: We should be going after them.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Did you know these people?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I do. I know the Stewarts. Dutch removes the rolled-up photo of the Stewarts from hi vest and hands it to Callaghan. He points at Maryanne.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: That’s Maryanne.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: She yours?  17. Dutch shakes his head, no.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I was working on it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK, LANDSCAPE- DAY
dialogues.text: We see the small cluster of homes overrun with Bluecoats, surrounded by an ocean of grass. We MOVE THROUGH the gras as if following something stalking the settlement...

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WASHBURNE CRICK, THE WILLIAMS HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Dobie has joined Dutch and Callaghan by the porch. Dutch finishes rolling a cigarette and hands it to the boy. H.V. SLAMS the door of the Williams House open, startling Dutch to his feet. Fuming, H.V. stalks across the porch, says to the nearest Bluecoat-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Send a scout to Fort Lincoln. Tell them to wagon up the gatlin and meet us at the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Are we going?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Not yet. Clay and Parcher emerge from the house.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Not till we put the Williams below ground. I christened those little girls, and I intend to give them a Christian burial.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: But the Stewarts are...

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We go off on horses that ain’t been rested, we won’t make it ten miles. We got time for a burial. Dutch clenches his fists, knows Parcher’s right. Dobie’s edging towards his horse and Dutch stops him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Let’s get the grain.  18. Dutch turns to attend to the horses. As Dobie starts to follow, Parcher takes the cigarette from him and smokes i

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: No reason to route the heathen if we're going to act like him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two dozen BLUECOATS, Parcher, Dutch, Dobie, Callaghan, an H.V. before four open graves. Clay, at the head-

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: God tests us, and when he takes the innocent, shows us we've failed. Jesus on the mount said that the meek would inherit the earth, and there they are, down init. I believe that was as much a commandment as a beatitude. Throughout the sermon, Dutch seems distracted, anxious to on the trail. He looks out at the plains.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: On that same mount, Jesus said, "blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called the children of God." We need to be those children. We got to work to make the earth a fit place for the meek. May God give the Williams family peace and paradise where we could not. And give us the wisdom and perseverance to carry on until we've finished His work. Amen.

dialogues.speaker: ALL
dialogues.text: Amen. Clay looks at the crowd for a moment. Dutch puts on his h ready to leave. The Bluecoats move to disperse. Clay launches into a hymn, "Alas, and Did My Savior Bleed Dutch takes his hat back off, the Bluecoats get back in l

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Alas, and did my savior bleed, And did my sovereign die. Would he devote that sacred head, For such a worm as I?  19. The others join in. H.V. sings reverently. Dobie sings wi his eyes closed. Bluecoats do the best they can. Dutch HUMS along. He notices an INDIAN standing among H.V bluecoats. This is TEN BEAR, Crow Tribe, dressed in a scout's mixture of Indian and Bluecoat garb. He sings alo perfectly. Dutch gawks. Ten Bear feels Dutch's eyes and meets his gaze.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Hundreds of hooves THUNDER over the plains. We still hear the HYMN being sung. Riders are scattered over an acre. Clay, Parcher, and Dobie ride grouped together. The Bluec ride in rough formation. Dutch is driving the mess wagon. H.V. rides at the head with Ten Bear.

dialogues.speaker: GROUP, (SINGING)
dialogues.text: Thy body slain, sweet Jesus, thine, And bathed in its own blood. While the firm mark of wraith divine, His soul, in anguish stood... As the post-lapped HYMN ends-

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Damnation. We ain't going to find kidnapped whites on a reservation.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I know it.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I ain't set to waste my time while they're scalping the men and raping our women.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We're about a day's ride shy of the Hunkpapa trail to Canada. S'where I'd be headed if I was a band of fugitive Indians. Clay nods, thinking. Dobie listens attentively.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We could set off alone.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm chewing the same cud, but there'd only be four of us.  20.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We have to find the Stewarts. If we can do that with Henry Victor's help, fine. If not, fine.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: -.-I guess you’ve had every chance to and ain't killed us yet. Though what we'd do if- Jump scare- Parcher suddenly LURCHES forward, his horse SCREAMS and stumbles, nearly throwing him. Clay’s reigns his own horse and grabs the lead of Parcher’s, steadying animal as Parcher jumps clear.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Mr. Parcher! What... Parcher gathers his wits.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: S'alright, Dobie. Must of stepped in a prairie dog hole. Parcher puts a calming hand on his horse’s muzzle.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (TO THE HORSE)
dialogues.text: There you go. S’alright...

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: How’s that leg? Parcher crouches and examines the fetlock.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: A little blood, but she’s standing alright. (to Dobie) Hey, Cowboy, hump on ahead, see how much further we're gonna press before camp.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Yessir. Parcher stands as Dobie spurs his horse forward. Once he' out of earshot-

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Why do you spend so much time rubbing that boy's belly? He already thinks you're Jesus Crocket.  21.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'm courtin' his mother. Parcher climbs up onto his horse.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: That's Gertrude Spacks' boy?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Skinny woman. Parcher looks at him. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (BONE DRY)
dialogues.text: Might as well just poke the boy. A beat. The first joke Clay’s made in months. Parcher lau Clay lets himself smile, they spur their horses forward. We TILT DOWN to what neither man saw, the “prairie dog ho that Parcher’s horse stepped in. Beneath the grass, the h is blood-colored, filled with dim GORE and shards of brok RIB-BONES...

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Dutch, driving the mess wagon, nods to Callaghan as he passes. The young black man veers his horse closer.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Who is Henry Victor's Indian? Callaghan looks towards the head of the group, where Ten gestures and talks low to H.V.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Ten Bear. He's a Crow Indian. And the man's paid for his work and free to leave.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yes?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: So he don't belong to Henry Victor.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK BLUECOAT, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Walnut!  22. Callaghan looks over. A BLACK BLUECOAT, several years Callaghan's junior,

dialogues.speaker: BLACK BLUECOAT
dialogues.text: Mr. Victor's canteen's dry. Callaghan nods. The Black Bluecoat veers off.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He called you Walnut.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah he did.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Why?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Thinks he's better'n me 'cause nobody ever owned him. I'm not enlisted. I cook for Fort Lincoln but I'm paid and I can leave any time. Understand?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Sure. (uncomfortable beat.) ..-How are you called?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: My name's Callaghan.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Callaghan. I am Martin Van Leijderova.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Shit, man, I can't say that. Dutch reaches out his hand. Callaghan shakes it, laughing

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I am also called Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Good to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE FRONT OF THE GROUP
dialogues.text: Dobie rides past Bluecoats and forward to where H.V. take pair of binoculars from Ten Bear.  23. H.V. points out something straight ahead to two BLUECOAT LIEUTENANTS. The Lieutenants nod and head back to their squads. Ten Bear hands H.V. a rifle. H.V. sees Dobie-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Take a look yonder. Dobie squints into the distance. A SHAPE in the grass.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Is that a horse? He hands Dobie the binoculars. Dobie peers through- DOBIE'S TELEPHOTO POV- A MINECONJOU INDIAN, dismounted fr his HORSE, walking in small, irregular circles and starin the ground. The Mineconjou glances up, looking almost directly at Dob then continues his search of the ground.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: He's seen us.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: You think I don’t know that?

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Then why ain't he run? ACROSS THE PLAINS- TWO COLUMNS of BLUECOATS, six men each break free of the group and CHARGE, galloping across the plains towards the lone Indian. DOBIE'S TELEPHOTO POV- The Indian sees the charging soldi He runs for his horse, a spotted mustang. The Mineconjou prepares to jump on his horse, as-— H.V. raises the rifle to his shoulder, takes aim... CRACK DOBIE'S POV- the horse jerks with the rifle's impact and twists sideways, falling to the ground. ACROSS THE PLAINS- The Indian jumps away from the falling beast as it kicks and pumps blood. The two columns of rid race towards him, flanking him North and South, closing i like pincers. The Indian turns and sprints West, tearing on foot throug the tall grass. The two columns of mounted soldiers close in, hooves THUNDER.  24. The SOUTHERN COLUMN sweeps in first, scooping around the Indian. He stops running and draws a knife. He turns away from the Southern Column just in time for t lead horse of the NORTHERN COLUMN to arrive, the mounted Bluecoat swinging his rifle like a club- CHUNK. The Indian catches the rifle flat across the side his head. His feet leave earth, he pinwheels through the air, head trailing blood, and SLAMS into the ground.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Clay crouches over the horse H.V. shot. Nearby, two BLUECOATS bind the Indian's hands to a wagon wheel. Blood leaks from the Indian's brow. Ten Bear crouches in front him, MURMURING at the captive. Parcher looks at the Indian; Dobie and Dutch stand nearby staring. H.V. stands in the center, well-satisfied.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: You didn't have to shoot his horse.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Christ, you gonna make us bury that, too? Clay stands and H.V. crosses to Ten Bear.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: What does he say?

dialogues.speaker: TEN BEAR
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Ask what he was looking for in the grass. Ten Bear leans in close and MURMURS words to the Indian, making signs with his hands. No response. Dutch pulls the photo of the Stewarts from his vest and h it to Clay. Clay nods and crouches next to Ten Bear, show the photo to the captive. To Parcher-

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Ask him. Parcher speaks in sub-titled Sioux, making signs with his hands as he speaks.  25.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <We need to find these white people. Bad Indians took. You help, we let you go.> No response. Clay stands, annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We don't have time for this. Let's keep moving.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <You Blackfoot? Minneconjou?> (no response) <Minneconjou, I think. Look like Bull Bear.> The Indian looks up sharply.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <But you no Bull Bear. Bull Bear dead. I bury him.> Parcher nods, offers a friendly grin.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <You Dull Knife. Son of Bull Bear.> The Indian, DULL KNIFE, stares at Parcher a few moments a then drops his gaze. Parcher stands-

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: His name's Dull Knife.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Carrying a prisoner's gonna slow us.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: I'd rather walk in the right direction than run with my head up my ass. We're running short of daylight, we'll camp here.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We're wasting time we ain't got, Henry. You know what's happening to those Stewart girls right now? Dutch looks sick. Clay presses the Stewart photo into H.V hands. H.V. is suddenly very conscious of the Bluecoats nearby, watching.  26.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: This isn't your outfit, Clay. If we need to raise any pigs, we’ll ask your advice. But renegade Indians are my job.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: If men like me and Will Parcher hadn't cleared this land of Indians, men like you would be dead on a spit and you know it.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: These soldiers are under my authority. Mine. So long as you ride with us, you are, too. He tries to hand the family photo back to Clay, who lets drop in the grass. Dutch appeals to Clay-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We’re not gonna stop...?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: That Indian doesn't know shit and wouldn't talk if he did.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR, (SMILING)
dialogues.text: He'll talk. Dutch picks the Stewart family photo out of the grass and puts it back in his vest.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: off-screen, Dull Knife SCREAMS. It's dinner time. None of the Bluecoats look up from their plates or away from thei conversations, they've grown used to the sound. Scattered CAMPFIRES. Men eat sociably, drink coffee.

dialogues.speaker: WE MOVE TO-
dialogues.text: Parcher, Clay, H.V., and Dobie sitting in a group near th campfire, finishing dinner. 0.S., Dull Knife SCREAMS. Onl Dobie looks over.

dialogues.speaker: WE MOVE TO-
dialogues.text: Dutch moving through the Bluecoats, trying to see what's happening to Dull Knife.  27. Ten Bear is crouching in front of the bound Minneconjou, the edge of the firelight, doing something to the soles o Dull Knife's feet. Dutch moves tangent to the two Indians circling around, trying to see what Ten Bear is doing. Du Knife SCREAMS. The cry echoes across the plains, no react from the Bluecoats. Ten Bear pulls a SMALL NOB away from Dull Knife's foot an sets it on the ground, something pale with a dark, shiny gloss. It could be metal, or it could be bone.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: You don't want to see that. Callaghan touches Dutch's shoulder and he jumps.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Walnut! ...Sorry. Callaghan, I mean. ...Has he talked?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Nah. Ain't even the point. Ten Bear stopped asking questions a half hour back. Come get some coffee. They walk towards the mess wagon. Callaghan pats his leg.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I was born with this leg gimp, flesh all withered and shrunk. Mr. Callaghan, the man that owned my mother named me Walnut because he thought I looked like one. I ain't partial to the name. They arrive at the wagon, Callaghan pours coffee. Dull Knife's SCREAMS dies down to pained BREATHING.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I can't see anything wrong with your leg.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: It's weak. Hurts most of the time.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: --.-I don't like Henry Victor.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: The man's a sack of horse-shit. Dutch grins in agreement. Then-  28.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'm Belgian. But they thought I was German on Ellis Island, so they put my name down as "Dutch."

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: What the hell kind of sense does that make? Dutch shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You come to this country alone?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (SHAKING HIS HEAD)
dialogues.text: I had a sister; the boat killed her and we put her in the water. All I kept of hers was a... I don’t know the English... a “broche.” Dutch gestures at his chest, shaping a brooch.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: -..I gave it to Maryanne Stewart. He looks at the ground. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I barely knew her but... I thought she might... Dutch swallows, takes a breath. Callaghan fills space-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Tell me your real name again.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Van Martjin Leijderova.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Shit. You want more coffee, Dutch?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yeah. Dutch glances over towards Dull Knife. He sits alone, bou to the wagon wheel, feet covered in bloody rags.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: He’s give up for the night, praise God. (considers, then-) Shit. I hope this gets me fired.  29. Callaghan grabs the bowl of scraps and carries it over to Dull Knife. He sets it on the ground next to him.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Go on, you can eat. It's alright. Dull Knife looks at the bowl of food, he wants it badly. looks at Callaghan. His eyes narrow, somewhere between menace and pity.

dialogues.speaker: DULL KNIFE, (SIOUX, SUBTTLED)
dialogues.text: <You’1ll be awake in your grave. You’1l be alive when they feed.> Callaghan furrows his brow, doesn’t understand. He nudges the bowl of food again.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Go on, eat. No reaction from Dull Knife. Callaghan SIGHS and walks ba towards the Wagon, where Dutch drinks coffee.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Walnut! My tobacco's dry!

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I got it. Dutch grabs a sack of tobacco and walks towards the fire.

dialogues.speaker: BY THE FIRE
dialogues.text: Parcher, Dobie, Clay, H.V., and a half-dozen BLUECOATS si They're drinking whiskey, coffee, they're rolling cigaret Dutch approaches. H.V. sees him.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Where's Walnut?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I brought tobacco.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Much obliged. H.V. takes the sack with one hand while he fishes in his with the other, pulling out a small TOBACCO POUCH that he tosses to Parcher. It looks like shriveled leather.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?  30.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Tobacco pouch.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: It's ugly as shit.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Came off an Injun. Big buck named Sackatabacky. A few Bluecoats LAUGH.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Oh, Jesus Christ. Parcher throws the shriveled tobacco pouch back to H.V., fills it as he tells a story, excessively proud-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: My daddy was one of the men behind the rifles that held off the Sioux at the battle for New Ulm. H.V. meaningfully shakes the pouch.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Henry Victor senior cut this off one of them Indians. Lends the tobacco a sweetness I've grown right partial to.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: It's a scrotum, Dobie. Dobie reacts. H.V. turns his attention to the boy.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: You know the story of New Ulm, boy?

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Yessir. My father died there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Well alright then. Did you know it was more American civilians than ever died in anything else? Not a soldier among ‘em. Six hundred dead by the lowest count. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: HENRY VICTOR (cont'd) The Sioux knew they couldn't face the army, so they attacked a town of unarmed farmers, women, children. H.V. is condescending, tells the story like Sunday School He licks, seals, and lights a scrotal-tobacco cigarette.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Yessir, I heard that.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: I hope you know your daddy died noble. I'll raise a drink to him and every man at this fire. We'll make sure we never see anything like that in this country again.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I'll drink to it.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Any reason's a good one. They raise flasks and enamel mugs, and drink. They fall respectfully quiet. The sudden silence reveals SLURPING and CHEWING. They all look over, to- Dull Knife, hungrily shoveling scraps from the bowl and i his mouth. H.V. exhales smoke.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Who fed my Indian? He stands, strides across the camp, and kicks the bowl ou Dull Knife's hands. Scraps fly.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: We don't find those settlers ‘til he talks, so he don't eat ‘til he talks. WHO FED MY GODDAMNED INDIAN? H.V. kicks Dull Knife in the Stomach, doubling him over. Chewed food flies from his mouth. H.V. picks up a loose stirrup, a metal buckle on two feet of leather strap, an impromptu LASH. Everybody watches him, Parcher and Clay g to their feet.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Walnut? Where are you? Walnut is absent. H.V. is rabid. Several tense moments, t  32.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: -..I fed him. Everybody turns to look at Dutch. H.V. stalks towards Dut with the stirrup / lash. He raises his arm...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: You ignorant son of a bitch...

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Henry. H.V. looks over. Clay has a hand on his gun. H.V. considers, then.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: ...-You raise that gun and all four of you'll be on ropes in an hour. Clay stands holding his gun. H.V. stands holding his lash Dutch looks like he's about to piss. Parcher gets up.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Christ, Henry, he was just gonna shoot you a little bit. And if Dutch fed him the same shit your cook fed us, he ain't no happier'n he was ‘fore he et. Leave it rest.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: This is my command. Mine. I can't have my authority undermined.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (TO DUTCH)
dialogues.text: Apologize to the man for undermining him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I am sorry. With his accent, it's hard to suss his sincerity. H.V. sp and shakes his head. To a Lieutenant-

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Bugle taps, we're bedding down. I want a three man watch until dawn. I want guns on the night. Anybody tries to sneak back into camp, anything moves, kill it.  33.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS CAMP-
dialogues.text: The Bluecoats and cowboys wrapped in their blankets, asle in small groups. Soft SNORES, the RUSTLING grass. A soft RATTLE rolls across the plains, like the largo creaking of an ungreased door. Almost a PURR. Dutch lies awake in his blankets, staring at the sky. A BLUECOAT SENTRY slouched by the fire struggles to keep eyes open, leaning on his rifle. The RATTLING PURR laps against him, each swell tugging him towards sleep. The so PURR rises again, the Sentry's eyes close. A BLUECOAT LIEUTENANT sleeps on his side on the edge of c spooning with his rifle. Dutch looks over the camp. Everybody else is asleep. Except Dull Knife. He sits awake, eyes sunken, desperate. He stares at the plains, watching the slowly waving grass Dutch lies back down, watching Dull Knife. Dull Knife's e shine in the campfire. Dutch closes his eyes. The Bluecoat Lieutenant, sleeping soundly on his side. We move to a short distance away, where a small circle of ea beneath the grass slowly starts to TREMBLE. The circle spreads, blades of grass fall. Five man-shaped FIGURES crawl towards him out of the gras They slink on all fours, silent. In the starlight and dyi campfire embers, we can just barely see their burnt-looki mottled flesh. Their movement is predatory, inhuman. The Bluecoat Lieutenant doesn't wake up when a TALON, an organic-looking blade touches the hollow between his coll bone and throat. RIIIP- the talon is dragged across the Lieutenant's neck, carving a deep trench in the flesh. The wound is deep but does not bleed, the scarlet blood instantly coagulating. The Lieutenant's eyes open and immediately hands on his b CLAMP DOWN hard, holding him immobile. The Lieutenant's eyes roll wildly. A RETCHING SOUND off screen, a SPLATTER, and then the Lieutenant's face goes slack. His eyes, still conscious, stare ahead. He is completely immobile. A beat. A RATTLING. A PURR. The Lieutenant is abruptly YANKED off-screen.  34.

dialogues.speaker: FROM A DISTANCE-
dialogues.text: Out in the plains, down in the grass, the dwindling campf offer a rich glow against the waving moonlit grass. SHAPE are being dragged out into the plains, the grass forming behind them, like a wake in water.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Bullshit! Bullshit! Bullshit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch opens his eyes. Most of the Bluecoats are already u Parcher is drinking coffee, getting his boots on. Dutch s up. H.V. storms around the camp like a child in a tantrum

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Somebody saw those yellow shit- heels desert. I will not god- damned believe four men left camp and nobody even god-damned stirred. Bluecoats hurry into boots and uniforms. Dutch sees Clay standing nearby, looking out at the grass.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (TO PARCHER)
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ‘Morning, sweetheart. Henry Victor lost some of his boys last night.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Where?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That's the question.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Somebody dragged ‘em off.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: The Indian didn't sleep. Dull Knife.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- ACROSS CAMP
dialogues.text: Dull Knife stares at the ground, beaten and exhausted. Parcher and Ten Bear crouch in front of him. Clay watches from nearby, whisky bottle in hand. H.V. paces.  35.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shit. You sure you didn't find him out front of a tobacco shop? H.V. snorts. Dutch approaches, tucking in his shirt.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BLUECOAT, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Sir? Mr. Victor? Henry Victor looks over, a YOUNG BLUECOAT is crouching ov one of the missing men's blankets.

dialogues.speaker: YOUNG BLUECOAT
dialogues.text: There's blood here, I think. Not a lot, but... H.V. stalks over, Clay on his heels. There is a six-inch smear of blood on the soldier's gray blankets.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: I've bled more from a pulled tooth. He turns and stalks back over to Dull Knife. Clay crouche and examines the blood. Parcher, crouching, speaks conversationally with Dull Knife.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SIOUX, SUB-TITLED)
dialogues.text: <Know you talk. Seen you talk, young boy.> No response from Dull Knife. Henry Victor is livid, his face nearly twitching, staring Dull Knife. Dull Knife stares back. H.V. steps on one of Dull Knife's bloody feet. Dull Knife SCREAMS through clenched teeth. Dutch turns away, sick. H.V. takes the weight off his foot. Dull Knife PANTS.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: What's he got to say now?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We already know that don't work. Parcher stands and turns away. Dull Knife catches his bre then the corner of his mouth twitches, he whispers-—

dialogues.speaker: DULL KNIFE, (SIOUX, SUB-TITLED)
dialogues.text: <I'm glad they like white men, too.>  36.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: TEN BEAR
dialogues.text: He says he likes white men.

dialogues.speaker: DULL KNIFE
dialogues.text: <The Burrowers.> Parcher listens intently.

dialogues.speaker: TEN BEAR
dialogues.text: He says about another tribe. Miners.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Miners? Indian miners?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: He didn't say "miners." Men mine. He used the word for when animals dig. Burrow, maybe. (To Dull Knife) <The tribe Burrowers? Last night?>

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Let my buck do his job, Will. Ten Bear leans in close to Dull Knife, cutting off Parche

dialogues.speaker: TEN BEAR
dialogues.text: <Where do we find the Burrowers?> Dull Knife nearly manages a smile despite the pain.

dialogues.speaker: DULL KNIFE
dialogues.text: <...They'1l find you.> He leans in, whispers just for Ten Bear-

dialogues.speaker: DULL KNIFE
dialogues.text: <Even if you do taste like white man by now.> They lock eyes. Ten Bear grabs Dull Knife's bloody mess o foot, SQUEEZES. Dull Knife SCREAMS. Clay steps over and SHOVES Ten Bear off with his boot, knocking him to the ground.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I've finished listening to that Indian scream.  37.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: He's shit-all for information anyway. We'll get our answers from the reservation.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: This ain't the Sioux, Henry. He just said the Burrowers.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: I don't have time to be second guessed. There's four white women out there've probably already... H.V. swallows his last words, grimacing.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: All the more reason we shouldn't be looking in the one place we know they ain't.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: We have to fight the enemy that's before us. We're going to the rez. Parcher's about to respond, when,

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Mr. Parcher! They look over. Dobie is waving from the grass near the e of camp. Clay and Parcher head over. H.V. moves in the opposite direction, towards his lieutenants.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE EDGE OF CAMP-
dialogues.text: Parcher crouches over a CIRCULAR INDENTATION of crushed g next to Dobie, just like at Washburne Crick. Clay continu past the circle, out towards the prairie.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (TO DOBIE)
dialogues.text: What do you think, Cowboy?

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: I dunno, sir.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (YELLING)
dialogues.text: There's another one. A third yonder. He points further North. Behind them, H.V.'s Bluecoats ar already packing up and heading West. Parcher nods to Clay showing that he heard the man.  38.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (TO DOBIE)
dialogues.text: Shitfire. Henry Victor'd rather pull fingers off the Sioux than follow the trail before us.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Sorry, sir?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...I think we're about set to quit our military escort.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POUNDING HOOVES. Dutch, Clay, Parcher, and Dobie gallop o through the grass, moving quickly now that they're alone. Dutch looks back at the train of Bluecoats quickly vanish in the distance. Clay, riding ahead, slows his horse to examine another SHALLOW PIT in a ring of crushed grass.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- SOUTHERN PLAINS
dialogues.text: Small, gnarled trees dot the landscape. The four riders c long shadows, climbing a gentle slope. From a distance, w show how tiny they are, how isolated.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch takes a swig from a bottle of whiskey. The four sit around a campfire, the last scraps of dinner in the ename pot on the fire's edge. They're unrolling blankets, getti ready for bed, passing the bottle. Dutch shows Dobie how to roll a cigarette. Clay takes an immensely satisfied drink and passes the bottle. Parcher takes it and grins.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Great god a-mighty, I'm tired. Ain't been rode this hard since we gulched the Darrows. Clay nods and hands him back the bottle. Parcher passes t bottle to Dutch, then nudges Dobie.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: On the trail of hostile Indians. What do you think, cowboy?  39.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE, (SMILING)
dialogues.text: It's alright. Dutch takes a swig and passes, then gets to his feet wear stretching.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Scratching his back, he walks away from the fire-

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Only a stone's throw from camp, Dutch is already out of t feeble, flickering throw of firelight. We can see how the darkness and endless space makes him nervous. The knee-deep grass is pitch-black in the moonlight. Dutc pulls out his pecker and pisses into the grass.

dialogues.speaker: BACK AT CAMP
dialogues.text: Dobie takes a swig of liquor, pretending like he enjoys i

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You been doing real good, Dobie.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Thank you, sir.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You oughta sleep. We'll be up and moving long before dawn. Only got a few days to find them Stewarts before we wouldn't want to. Dobie starts to ask him what he means, then holds his ton

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch pisses into the grass, looking out at the few gnarl dwarfish trees shaking in the wind. His eyes are a little glassy with liquor. He YAWNS. From a distance- Dutch starts to button up his pants. We see him clearly silhouetted against the flickering light camp, an easy target. A SHAPE passes in front of the camera.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Clay takes a pensive drink, sitting on his blankets.  40.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: You think those men last night deserted?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You mean ruther'n got drug off? Clay nods. Beat. Parcher shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: F’they did, I hope they died fast. You ever heard of an Indian tribe called the Burrowers? Clay shakes his head no, and pulls a BIBLE from his vest.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We'll stand watch, two hour shifts.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch turns and starts walking back towards camp. He does hear a SNAP a dozen yards away. He continues towards camp, leaving frame. We linger on th dark landscape behind him- Against the waving grass, between the small, gnarled tree it's impossible to see clearly. But we can just make out- TWO SHAPES, moving towards the fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dobie curls into his blankets and closes his eyes. Parche already looks asleep. Only Clay sits upright, holding Parcher's rifle, reading his bible by fire-light. Dutch walks into the edge of the firelight. He doesn't se the DARK SHAPE looming behind him. Clay looks up at Dutch, then past him. A momentary look o concern crosses his face. He puts his Bible in his vest. The grass sways in the wind behind Dutch. Clay jerks the rifle up and levels it, almost directly at Dutch. Dutch freezes.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What...  4l.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: Don't shoot! Dutch jumps like something bit him. Parcher comes out of his blankets, cocking his revolver a sits up. Dobie scrambles to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: It's me, it's Callaghan, Mr. Henry- Victor's cook. Leading his horse, Callaghan emerges from the darkness be Dutch, and into the firelight.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shitfire, Walnut. You alone?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Yeah. Parcher drops his pistol.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: You trying to get shot? Callaghan moves in towards the fire, realizing how close getting shot he was.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Great Christ. Tie up your horse and set. You missed dinner. Callaghan nods thanks to Parcher, then nods hello to Dutc Dutch nods back.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS CAMP-
dialogues.text: Callaghan sits with the others, their conversation alread progress.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I can't rightly account for the others. Didn't even know they was missing until now.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Deserting the army's a felony. They could hang you for that and jail us for riding with you.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I didn't desert. Weren't enlisted.  42. Clay looks at Parcher, who raises his eyebrows in questio Clay nods.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Well, if you're riding with us, you're working for us.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: That's fine.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: It's nasty work in unfriendly country. You want to make it back to the ranch, you'll follow and do as your told. Callaghan nods. Pauses, then-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Can I ask, which one of y'all is boss?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We're partners.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Listen to Parcher, do what Clay says.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'll be dog, the German's been paying attention... Welcome to the outfit, Walnut. Parcher reaches out and shakes Callaghan's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the lead-gray light, the five riders course across the grasslands.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- DAY
dialogues.text: One of the round SHALLOW PITS of crushed grass and churne earth. The five riders pass in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Coffee's on the campfire, Callaghan dishes out food. The grass moves in the wind around them.  43.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS, HUNKPAPA TRAIL- LATE AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Dutch, Dobie, and Callaghan ride in a loose group through grass. Dobie pulls the mess wagon. Parcher and Clay have ridden ahead and sit talking. The three ride close enough to hear their conversation-

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: -..seen the last of them pits a half day back. The trail before them is little more than a slight depres in the earth, stretching roughly East and West.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'd say we follow the trail, but it's your call.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: .-.-Take your rest. I need to ruminate. Parcher SIGHS. They all dismount, except Clay, who rides few paces forward. Dutch walks over to Parcher, who takes a swig of whiskey.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Which way are we going?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You’1l go whatever direction we tell you to, I guess. Parcher offers Dutch the whiskey. Dutch drinks, then give the bottle back. He walks back towards Dobie and Callaghan, grabs a small stone from the ground, and chucks it at a gnarled, dead t eighty feet distant. The stone makes a pleasant TOK sound against the trunk. Dobie grins at Dutch, impressed. The boy grabs a rock off the ground, aims, and throws it at the tree. It sails pas well wide. Dobie leans down, searches among the grass roo and picks up another stone. He chucks it at the tree, and again misses. Callaghan sees the game and joins in, picking up stones a throwing them at the tree. He misses twice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch watches the two try to repeat his throw, smiling as they keep missing. It’s a moment of near-relaxation, the three suddenly boys again. Dobie steps forward into the grass, and stoops down, searching the dark earth for another stone... Dutch pulls a piece of grass from its sheath and chews on tender base. FROM A DISTANCE- we see the five men alone in an ocean of grass, vulnerable. Dobie can’t find another stone. He pushes some grass asid and pauses. There’s an 8-inch lock of BLONDE HAIR pressed into the dark earth. Dobie’s hand hovers over the strands for a moment before lifting it from the ground. It’s human hair. He gives it gentle tug. SCHRT, the lock of hair RIPS free from the earth, a blood postage stamp of wet SCALP dangling from the end. Dobie’s jaw drops. He GASPS and flings the hair away. Callaghan steps over, looks down. There’s a patch of OPEN WOUND in WHITE FLESH in the ground. He kneels and pushes some looses soil from around the wou in the earth, revealing SKIN. Dutch walks slowly towards them. He sees the flung bloody lock of hair suspended in the tall grass. He spits out th piece of grass he was chewing on, looks at the ground whe Callaghan is pushing away the soil... Callaghan'’s digging reveals a WOMAN’S EYE, crusted with staring up at the sky. Dobie SCREAMS. The buried woman’s pupil CONTRACTS.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS, HUNKPAPA TRAIL- DUSK
dialogues.text: The woman, waifishly thin, blonde, lies on the grass. She in a coma and a filthy gingham dress. Grass stains, dirt, and dried blood mark her pale skin. There is a SOFT SCRATCHING noise off-screen, like a cat pawing at a door. sounds like its coming from inside of her.  45.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: She's breathing. Parcher is crouched next to her. He tries to press her eyelids down, but they won't stay shut. Her eyes keep creeping open, staring without motion at the dark blue sk The other four men stand over her, looking down.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: She's not one of the Stewarts.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Then who is she? Dutch shakes his head. We'll call the woman AUDREY. Parcher pushes Audrey's head gently to the side, better exposing a deep, six-inch wound tore roughly into her nec and shoulder. There's no blood but that inside the wound itself, thickened like raspberry jam.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Same as Williams' wife.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. And she should have bled out more, too. Parcher leans in. Small WHITE GROWTHS line the wound, clustered like frog eggs. The thickened blood glistens.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: It's still moist. Maybe infected. Parcher reaches out and touches gently around the angry p edges of the wound. He pushes back the edge of Audrey's collar, revealing a small GOLD CRUCIFIX on a chain. Dutch leans in to get a better look. The fungal-looking white growths surround the cross in the wound.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: She got any other marks on her?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You got eyes. Clay doesn't respond. The SCRATCHING sound is still there from somewhere inside Audrey.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Something's scratching.  46. Callaghan and Dobie look at him, but nobody responds. Parcher lifts one of the woman's arms, there are BRUISES running up and down it. More bruises on her neck. He lifts up a piece of her dress, looks at the long verti tears and green stains on the fabric.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: She's been drug a spell.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: What else?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: What else you want, John?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Did the Indians rape her? Dobie's eyes bug out, he gulps back shock. Dutch is listening hard, the SCRATCHING sound is still audible.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: How the hell am I supposed to know?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Something’s scratching inside her.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I hear it, too. Dutch crouches down, across from Parcher, over Audrey's f Audrey's eyes stare unmoving upward. As Dutch gets closer Audrey, the SCRATCHING gets louder. He moves down towards the fringes of her torn dress. The SCRATCHING gets louder. One of her shoes is gone. The SCRATCHING is coming from inside her other shoe.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It's in her shoe.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Pull it off. Dutch looks at Clay, then reaches for the shoe and pauses The SCRATCHING is fervent, insect-like.  47. Dutch pulls off the shoe. Her foot is bare beneath. Audrey's fourth toe is wiggling Nobody's sure how to react. Audrey's toe wiggles, her chest barely moves with her breathing, she stares unmoving at the sky.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS CAMP-
dialogues.text: From beside the campfire, Dutch can just barely see Parch and Clay standing out on the prairie, past the edge of th flickering firelight. They're deep in conversation, shari a bottle of whisky. Dutch is crouched over Audrey, cleaning the dirt off of h face with canteen water. Callaghan sits on the ground nearby, blowing on his coffee to cool it. Dobie stands on the other side of the fire, anxious, kick at the embers. He keeps looking at Audrey, building up to something. Dutch pushes Audrey's head to the side and tries to wipe the scab sticking the gold cross to her wound. Her head keeps slipping out of his grasp. To Callaghan-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Can you hold her head?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Naw, man. I'm not touching her.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: She can't mind.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: It ain't her I'm worried about. Dobie approaches from around the fire, anxious. He points Audrey-

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Is that what rape is?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Is that what rape is?  48.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: No...

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: We don't know what them Indians did to her. Dobie stares at Audrey, thinking hard, then turns sharply away and walks out towards Parcher and Clay. Callaghan bl on his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Parcher and Clay speak softly, low enough to escape the others' ears. Dobie approaches in the background, hearing the conversation already in progress-—

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: --.-don't know anything about him. That's the point.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: And what do we know about Dutch?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: He's white.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: But he ain't American.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I'm not about to leave a helpless white woman alone with a negro we don't know. They got... urges. It's scientific. Dobie hovers on the edges of their conversation, hoping t noticed, too nervous to butt in.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shit-fire, everybody's got urges. That's why God invented free will, morals. And maybe you ain't met enough Occidentals to know it, but they got a lot more free will than they got morals. What do you want, Dobie? Dobie's off guard. Parcher waits. Clay looks annoyed.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Um... Is that... What's rape?  49. Parcher looks at him and grins. He looks at Clay.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That'll do.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: He's just a boy.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Exactly. (louder, to Dobie) Cowboy, we got a job for you.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PRAIRIE CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The campfire is dying down. Lying awake in his blankets, Dutch stares at the small flames dancing over the embers. Callaghan, Clay, and Dobie are asleep in their blankets, scattered around the fire. Parcher sits by Audrey with hi rifle across his knees, looking out over the plains. Dutch admits he won't sleep, climbs out of his blankets, crosses to Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Dutch. You're watch ain't another hour yet.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I couldn't sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (NODDING)
dialogues.text: Dark business. Finding that woman means we're on the right trail.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Why would they bury her alive?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: +..-I dunno. It's a miracle she ain't dead.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What if they buried Maryanne? Parcher spits into the fire. Dutch remains determined-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We'll find her.  50. They sit in silence for a few moments. The fire light reflects in Audrey's eyes. Dutch looks at the glint of go stuck in the wound on her neck.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: ..-What about her cross? (Parcher looks over,) It's stuck in her... in the blood. Parcher peers at the cross and nods.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...-Maybe that ain't good. You got religion, Dutch? Parcher takes the cross between his thumb and forefinger, avoiding touching the thick red blood glistening beneath.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I never did. Parcher pulls on the cross. It's stuck in the gore, pulls the wound, Audrey's torn flesh puckering.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You should get some. Might balance the account of your upbringing. Parcher tugs and the cross RIPS free of the wound. Parche hand jerks away unexpectedly and the gold chain around Audrey's neck SNAPS.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Oh. Shoot. There's a dark spot in the wound where the cross was, surrounded by the faint outline of a cross in the tiny wh growths.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Here, it's yours. Parcher presses the cross into Dutch's hand.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What do I do with it?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Hellfire, I don't know. Find comfort in your maker. Take this, too. It's your watch.  51. He shoves his rifle into Dutch's hand and crosses to his blankets. Dutch holds the cross and the rifle. He wipes t blood off the crucifix, rubbing it clean on his jeans. He holds the cross up to the light. In the glint of the fire, he can just see the small white FUNGAL GROWTHS clinging to its surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch pulls tight the ropes holding Audrey to the wagon. She's lying face-up, eyes still open, on piled blankets. Dobie's horse is tied to the wagon. The other four horses are packed with provisions and camping gear. They're all getting ready to leave. Parcher, to Dobie-

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Once you get to Fort Lincoln, stay with her, we'll pick you up on our way back.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: I could catch up with you in a day or two.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We don't have more'n a day or two ‘fore those missing are corpses. Or worse. Parcher leans in conspiratorially to Dobie.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Wouldn't trust any other man in the outfit to do the job. Dobie grins, proud.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Don't ride at night lest you want to break old Sparrow's leg. Parcher pats the flank of Dobie's horse.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: I know it, sir. Dutch looks at the rising sun, still low over the horizon then at Audrey's unblinking eyes. He tries to push her li down one more time and again they slowly slide open.  52.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Enough. Let's go. Dutch looks over, everybody's mounting up. Dutch takes off his derby and puts it low over Audrey's h so that it shields her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're sinking slowly towards the ground. Various shots, always lower: Dobie riding South alone with the comatose woman wearing Dutch's hat. The other four RIDE HARD North The sun climbs and we sink. Bleached buffalo bones mark t passing hours like sundials. The four riders pass the charred scrap remainders of a te village at a gallop. Lower and lower, the four ride into the NORTHERN PLAINS, varied country, we can see mountains in the distance. The land rises and falls, is dotted with small groups of tree scrub and silver-barked birch. SOUTHERN PLAINS- Still sinking. Dobie sees FOUR FIGURES o foot ahead, walking the trail towards him. NORTHERN PLAINS- Still sinking. Dutch and the others ride into scattered birch trees, almost glowing in the gloamin We sink into the earth, past PALE SHAPES that could be bo and might be moving.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BIRCH FOREST- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Clay and Parcher ride at the front, Dutch and Callaghan a the rear. The forest is unnaturally quiet, we can hear th trees moving in the wind. To Dutch-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I don't like this quiet.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Hold your peace. There's an urgency in his voice. Parcher looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Yonder.  53. Clay nods ahead and halts his horse. A FIGURE is approach through the tangle of birch. Parcher puts his hand on his gun and draws his horse to a stop alongside. He squints i the forest.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I can't see him.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Looks Sioux. Dutch and Callaghan draw to a stop along side. Dutch sees Parcher's hand on his gun.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What...?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Hush. Dutch puts a hand on his gun. Callaghan follows suit. A BIRD WHISTLE comes from behind them, possibly a human imitation of the sound.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shit. They got us flanked. I'm counting on you boys with young eyes to see that man draw his gun. Don't be bashful about shooting back if he does. The Figure gets closer, coming through the trees, the sti in his hand might be a RIFLE. Another WHISTLE. Dutch looks back, towards the sound, nothing but the visual noise of birch trees. Dutch turns back facing forward and sees a SIOUX WARRIOR emerge from the forest ahead, barely twenty feet away. Th Sioux Warrior raises his rifle... Dutch draws his pistol and FIRES. The Sioux turns and sprints back into the forest. Before Dutch can fire a sec shot, Clay swings a huge arm and knocks him from his hors Dutch drops his gun and CRASHES to the ground painfully.
