The four horses, gunshot spooked, prance and turn. Callaghan's horse glances a hoof across Dutch's brow with CRACK like wood breaking. Dutch CRIES OUT and puts hands his bleeding head.  54.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Goddamnit! That was a greeting! Clay trots his horse a few steps forward into the birch. Parcher looks forward to him.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We got trouble?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: I expect. Dutch sits up, looks at the blood on his hands. There's a two-inch gash on his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'm shot.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Oh Jesus Christ amighty. Walnut's horse kicked you. And you deserve worse. Clay rides back to the group.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: So what do we do?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: We keep at it. He turns to Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: You so much as touch your gun without my say so and I'll holster it in your ass. Understand? On the ground, holding his bleeding head, Dutch nods.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Dobie cautiously approaches a FAMILY OF SIOUX on foot. An OLD MAN, OLD WOMAN, TEENAGE GIRL, and a BOY. Dobie and the family, both sides nervous, exchange pantom greetings and trade. Dobie reaches a slab of beef jerky f the wagon and offers it. The Old Man takes it, nodding an smiling. He gestures and speaks softly to the Girl, who pulls a twist of tobacco from her pouch. The Old Woman, at the wagon's side, inspects Audrey. She sees the wound on Audrey's neck.  55. Suddenly the Old Woman is TALKING fast and low in SIOUX. Old Man steps forward and takes a look.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Hey, now... Don't... Dobie puts a hand on his gun. The Old Woman's still TALKI pointing at the gash with it's small white growths. The Old Man turns, doesn't even look at Dobie, grabs the and Teenage Girl, and all four walk swiftly away. Dobie, confused, watches them go. The Sioux walk swiftly the trail, they don't even look back.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BIRCH FOREST- DUSK
dialogues.text: The world tilts uneasily around Dutch. He gingerly touche the WOUND on his head, the skin angry and pink around it. The four are riding in a rough group through the trees, cautious, all eyes scanning for Indians. The birch have become even more dense, visibility is minimal. Parcher is riding point, Clay is bringing up the rear. Callaghan pulls his horse over next to Dutch's.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I’1l live.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Mr. Parcher told you to shoot. It’s moral support and Dutch takes it, nodding.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What does it mean, “to holster in the ass?"

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Means he’s sweet on you. Clay suddenly appears beside them, spurring his horse for towards Parcher. Callaghan and Dutch fall silent.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (TO PARCHER)
dialogues.text: I don't like this. You think that Indian was Burrower tribe?  56.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Looked Sioux. But there’s more flavors of Sioux than I can count.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: Why ain’t we heard of them before?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Can’t say. I expect they'll introduce themselves shortly. The Kraut ain't made us the most popular white men in Dakota.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY, (NODDING)
dialogues.text: I'm libel to drop him when we get back.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Amen to that.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I stay on until we find the Stewarts. Dutch has pulled up beside Clay and Parcher. He’s determi blood flaking from his brow. Clay nods, assenting.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That might not be so far off. F’that Indian you shot at wanted to talk, he wanted to trade. And the only thing he’d have we might want is white folks.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You mean the Stewarts?

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: It's possible. But we don’t trade for whites.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: But it means we’re close. Clay nods.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: ...We're pushing four days now they been gone.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Does it change anything if this is revenge rather'n rescue?  57.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: This isn’t.... We can still find her. Even if she’s been.... hurt. Parcher looks at Clay, waits for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: CLAY
dialogues.text: He’s right. We ain’t found bodies. We don’t sleep tonight, we don’t stop-- Clay's neck EXPLODES. The CRACK of a rifle. Blood splatte backwards, spraying Dutch and Callaghan. Jugular spray pu obscenely skyward as Clay falls backwards off his horse. Parcher's horse bucks as he draws his revolver. Dutch wip blood from his eyes. Callaghan draws in a breath to scream, another CRACK, and horse jerks violently backwards, eyes wild. Blood pours f behind its ear and the animal falls, pinning Callaghan’s ankle beneath the saddle. Clay SLAMS onto his back on the ground, blood pumping fro his neck. He kicks at the earth, eyes rolling in his head Parcher grabs his rifle and jumps off his horse. More GUNSHOTS echo from the surrounding forest, WAR CRIES from every direction. Dutch scrambles off his horse. Callaghan's horse, lying o the ground, pinwheels its legs and froths at the mouth. Callaghan pulls frantically, trying to free his leg. Splinters fly off the birch trees above at the impact of bullets. BLAM, BLAM, and WAR CRIES. Dutch fires his pisto back wildly. Parcher crawls over. Clay is fish-belly white where he is bloody. His eyes have stopped moving. Dutch crawls to Callaghan, still pinned beneath the saddl

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Stop pulling. Callaghan relaxes his leg. Dutch lifts the saddle and Callaghan pulls free. Parcher crawls over to Callaghan's horse and SHOOTS it in head. The horse twitches and stops moving.  58.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Get over here! Parcher scrambles behind the horse, between it and some deadfall, finding an impromptu bunker. Callaghan crawls o to join him, Dutch close behind. BLAM, BLAM, the gunshots continue. The WAR CRIES echo fro every direction. Dutch, Parcher, and Callaghan lie on the ground between t horse and the deadfall. Dutch fumbles more bullets into t chamber of his gun. THUNK, a bullet slams into the corpse Callaghan's horse. Callaghan raises up with his pistol and Parcher puts a ha on his arm, stopping him.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Don't waste your bullets. We'll shoot when they're close enough to kill. WAR CRIES. THUNK, the horse twitches at the impact of another bullet. BLAM... BLAM... the rifle shots slow. We can hear FOOTSTEPS, the CRUNCH of dry leaves. Dutch peeks out from behind the horse. Clay is staring ba at him, impossible to tell if the man is dead or not. A SIOUX WARRIOR emerges from the trees behind Clay, carry a pistol and a maul. Dutch's eyes widen. The warrior paus over Clay's corpse, raises the maul, and SKRUNCH, sinks i into Clay's face, nearly taking off the dead man's jaw. BLAM, Dutch cringes at the sound of the rifle directly ov his head. The Sioux Warrior spins and falls to the ground with a shoulder wound. Parcher shucks another round into his rifle as he drops b to the ground behind the horse. BLAM, BLAM, BLAM, rifle s and WAR CRIES answer Parcher's fire. Dutch presses himself to the ground, Callaghan likewise. Parcher waits, gets an eye over the horse. Another SIOUX is pulling the first to his feet. Parcher springs up and BLAM, shoots the second Sioux dead in the chest. Parcher drops back behind the horse. BLAM, a single shot answers. Scattered WAR CRIES die off.  59. Parcher, Dutch, and Clay lay behind the dead horse. They realize that they are laying in a pool of horse blood, spreading crimson against the fallen, silver leaves of bi They can hear the PANTING and MOANS of pain as the should wounded Sioux gets to his feet and runs into the forest. RUNNING, the CRUNCH of dead leaves scatter in every direction. Parcher, Dutch, and Clay lie behind the horse try to catch their breath. FROM ABOVE- we see that they line up like a zodiac. Three men lying in blood behind the dead horse, Clay dead on hi back in his own blood, the chest-shot Sioux dead a stone' throw away. Sudden silence with the cessation of gunfire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- DUSK
dialogues.text: The plains are unnaturally quiet. Dobie softly whistles ALAS AND DID MY SAVIOR BLEED. He's assembled a small camp fire and laid out his blankets a s distance from the mess wagon, where Audrey lies, still wearing Dutch's derby.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: I guess we can make you a might more comfortable. Don't uh... Don't think I'm being forward or nothing. Dobie approaches Audrey, a little nervous. He shyly grins and lifts her from the wagon. Her eyes look up at the sky Dutch's hat falls from Audrey's head and onto the ground. Dobie lays Audrey on a thick pad of blankets.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: There. Now, lemme... Dobie pushes a rolled blanket beneath her head like a pil In the strange silence of the plains, we can hear the SCRATCHING of Audrey's toe in her shoe.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Well, now. Right civilized. Dobie looks down at Audrey. His head bobs down towards he and he pauses. He grins nervously, looks around at the em plains. Then ducks down and pecks Audrey a quick KISS on lower, parched lip. While kissing her, the SCRATCHING STO  60.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Good night. Dobie looks down at her, a goofy smile on his face. The SCRATCHING in her shoe starts again. Dobie furrows his br puzzled. He looks at the shoe. He reaches out timidly and covers Audrey's eyes. The SCRATCHING stops. He takes his hand away, the SCRATCHING starts again. Dobie takes a breath, repeats the experiment. Covers her eyes and the SCRATCHING stops, uncovers and it starts aga

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: Jesus. You're awake. Dobie looks like he could cry.

dialogues.speaker: DOBIE
dialogues.text: You're... I'm so sorry. What did... What did they do to you? Dobie looks down her. She stares sightlessly at the sky, toe SCRATCHING in her shoe. Dobie moves off to his own blankets. Beneath the SCRATCHING, out in the plains, we can hear th same RATTLING CREAK, a soothing GURGLE.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (WHISPERING, V.O.)
dialogues.text: Christ amighty, is he asleep?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BIRCH FOREST- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch opens his eyes, putting a hand to the angry wound splitting his scalp and GROANING.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I’m awake.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: God damn if you ain't the dumbest white man I ever met. They're all still crouched between the dead horse and the pile of fallen birch. A stiff BREEZE moves through the forest, RATTLING the leaves.  61. Dutch blearily wipes at his face. Dried blood flakes off like scales.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I ain't heard a thing in hours.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: How long are we gonna wait here?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: They could be waiting in ambush. They sit in the broken moonlight.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: .--Billy's starting to smell. Parcher and Dutch look at him for clarification.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: S'what I named the horse.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That's my name. Small grins from Dutch and Callaghan.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I didn't know that, Mr. Parcher. Real sorry.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shit fire. The horse is dead, Walnut, call it what you like. Parcher shakes his head. Then reaches out with a gloved hand, and pulls a bunch of leafy vines from the base of a tree. He squints at it in the darkness. Parcher makes a CLICKING noise in his throat, thinking.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: That's poison oak, ain't it?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Looks it.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ---I tell you what. Put your gloves on, pile up as much of this stuff as you can. We ain't waiting for dawn.  62.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of Dobie's peaceful, sleeping face. A TEARING sound, ripping flesh. RATTLES and HISSES, something like snakes or insects. Dob blearily opens his eyes. A shadow withdraws from over him, shifting in the firelig A SIX INCH CUT freshly gouged in Dobie's neck. The FIGURE crouching over Dobie is back-lit by the fire, barely discernible. It grabs Dobie by the arm and rolls h up onto his side. Dobie struggles for a moment, thrashing an arm, before a RETCHING sound precedes a HOT SPLASH of liquid hitting hi neck. Dobie's thrashing arm goes limp. His eyes freeze forward, staring across the camp fire. Beyond the camp fire, concealed by their flames, THREE MO FIGURES, like small men, crouch over Audrey. The shifting firelight barely reveals them. They're on Audrey as if working on her. They arch their backs and tug, making SLURPING noises, like geriatrics sucking tapioca. The Figure over Dobie drops him and he rolls helplessly o his back, eyes staring upwards. The Figure is out of his sight too quickly for Dobie to clearly see it. Thick liqu drips onto Dobie's face and neck. Where the bile drops, it STEAMS quickly away, leaving tin WHITE GROWTHS. The RATTLING and GURLGING sounds continue. Dobie is left momentarily alone, staring upwards. There is fear in his unmoving eyes. The LITTLE FINGER of his left hand WIGGLES. Dobie's unmov eyes stare upward. The finger WIGGLES. THREE FIGURES return to him, crouching over him, blocking the light of the fire. They cluster on the periphery of Dobie's vision. THREE MORE join the crowd, completely casting Dobie into shadow. A SEVENTH. Dobie is unable to turn his eyes and look at the hands th grab onto his arms and legs. He's lifted from the ground suddenly moving away from camp. Tall grass flies past as he's dragged helplessly through planes. Dobie stares up at the grass, the starry sky beyo  63. He is dragged by the seven Figures far out into the plain well out of the firelight's range. And suddenly dropped. We hear GRASS TORN from the ground. The sounds of EARTH MOVING. Dobie, staring upwards, cannot see what is happening. The Figures PUFF and HISS as they dig, pushing earth aside. The monstrous hands roll Dobie over once, twice, and into SHALLOW PIT. Dobie lands face-up in a hole in dark earth size of a coffin. From the edges of his vision, he sees the dim outline of Figures pushing freshly dug earth towards him. They cover him from the feet-up in about four inches of soil. They cover his belly, his chest. A thin layer of dirt is pushed over his face, until only eye barely peeks out of the rich soil, one nostril is lef free to breath. We hear the Figures turn and move off. The sounds again o GRASS TEARING and EARTH MOVING and then sudden SILENCE. In the dark soil beneath an ocean of grass, Dobie's eye stares helplessly out across the plains. Tiny particles o soil around his nostril shake with his weak breathing. Several feet away from his eye, a tiny patch of earth is shaking a little bit, as if a mole were trying to surface We SINK down into that earth, and several inches below it find Dobie's little finger WIGGLING.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The forest is misty, the first hints of sub-horizon lead- colored light off in the distance. Dutch and Callaghan ar sweating, steam rising from their bodies as they work. Th pile of poison oak is twenty feet long and four feet high Nearby, Parcher ties John Clay's corpse to a TRAVEAU. It' like a tight hammock woven between two birch saplings tie the horse's saddle, one end left to drag on the ground. Callaghan throws another bunch of leaves onto the pile an pauses, breathing.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: They used to make us burn this shit in Georgia.  64.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Knew a man got caught downwind and inhaled the smoke. Bled from his lungs for two days and then died. Drowned in his own blood.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (OFF-SCREEN)
dialogues.text: You boys about set? Dutch and Callaghan look over. Parcher stands wiping his hands on his jeans. John Clay's blanket-wrapped corpse is secured to its sling.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We're set.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Good, then get her burning and let's go. Parcher turns towards the corpse of the dead Sioux, still lying face-up on the ground, as Dutch fishes a box of mat from his vest, gives a handful to Callaghan.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: This don't seem right.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don’t like it either. But we don’t have time. This gets us back on the trail. Callaghan doesn't answer, but strikes a match and touches to a twist of paper buried in the brush. Dutch does the same, and soon the poison oak begins to burn and smoke. Dutch and Callaghan back quickly away, covering their mou BLAM, BLAM. They both jump at the sudden sound of gunfire They look back at Parcher, who walks away from the dead Sioux's corpse with a smoking pistol. The Sioux's eyes have been shot out of his head.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. BIRCH FOREST- PRE-DAWN
dialogues.text: Dutch, Callaghan, and Parcher, with Clay's corpse in tow, ride away from the quickly growing flames behind them. Th look like emissaries from hell, the reflected firelight dancing off of the trees' silver bark.  65. They ride into the forest, quickly leaving sight of Callaghan's dead horse and the dead, desecrated Sioux. Clay's traveau bounces roughly along the ground. The wind carries the deadly yellow-tinged smoke through t forest behind them, glowing red in the fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN PLAINS / FOREST EDGE- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch sits on the ground, using a hatchet to knock the cr piece of a small birch crucifix into the riser. A few yards off, Callaghan and Parcher finish shoveling d onto Clay's grave. Parcher, winded, lowers his shovel and steps over to Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Here I thought you ain't had any religion.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Sorry? Parcher gestures at Dutch's cross.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: So we'll know where he's buried. Parcher nods, wipes sweat from his brow and grabs an open bottle of whisky.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You might should think about Jesus. That Bible's done a lot of good in the world. Dutch nods, non-committal.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: .-.-And maybe leave off that cross. If them Indians know a white man's buried here, they're liable to dig him up and tear out his eyes, make him blind in the spirit world. Parcher looks away, his eyes shining with tears, and take drink. Dutch stands and throws the cross towards the birc forest. The cross tumbles slowly, end over end through th sky, and vanishes in the grass. Parcher sniffs and spits, drinks more whisky. Callaghan finishes his work and leans on his shovel.  66.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: This mean we're heading back?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (SURPRISED)
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Hell, no. John Clay'd piss on us from heaven if we turned back now.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: And the Stewarts. You said we’re close.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. We ride night and day, we can overtake ‘em on the far side of those woods, kill the redskin that shot John and get your woman back. Dutch mounts his horse. Callaghan pauses, looking down at Clay's grave.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You want to say some words for Mr. Clay?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SHAKING HIS HEAD)
dialogues.text: That was his job.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHER PLAINS- DAY
dialogues.text: The three ride hard. Callaghan and Dutch have heavy bags under their eyes. Parcher smokes, eyes narrow and red.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch rubs his face roughly. His and Callaghan’s horses h drifted a stone’s throw behind Parcher’s. The three are riding more slowly now, the need for sleep overtaking the Callaghan looks exhausted. Ahead, Parcher’s head is bowed, eyes closed. He’s asleep his horse. Dutch sees it, and looks at Callaghan.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: How do you think he does that? Sleeps on his horse?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't know. Dutch looks up at the glaring sun. His skin is sunburned.  67.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Wish I had my hat.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS- DUSK
dialogues.text: Parcher’s awake again. All three men are bleary-eyed and pallid, swaying with the motion of their horses. They sta ahead through heavy lids. There’s a gentle PURRING rollin in off the plains. Callaghan's eyes creep shut. Their three horses start to climb a rise. Dutch’s horse catches up with Parcher’s. Parcher is asleep again. Dutch turns and looks back towards Callaghan. Callaghan's gone, the horse he was riding clops along beh them without a rider.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Hey. Callaghan’s gone. Parcher snorts awake and looks back. He’s nonchalant--

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: When did we misplaced our Negro?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: While you were sleeping.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I wasn’t asleep. Dutch turns his horse and spurs it back a few yards.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Callaghan! ...Callaghan! He looks around; it’s an ocean of grass, the low sun cast long shadows off the waving blades. Dutch can see for mil and there’s no sign of Callaghan at all. The PURRING continues, masked slightly by the GURGLING of small stream nearby. Dutch looks at Parcher, anxiety in his eyes. Either one o them could have vanished as easily. Dutch’s horse trots forward, Dutch scanning the grass. Parcher pulls his horse forward in the background. Callag is simply gone; the grass swallowed him whole.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: ..-Hey.  68. Parcher and Dutch turn. No sign of Callaghan, until... he wearily pushes himself up out of the grass maybe fifteen away, right between the two horses.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Get Walnut back on his horse, we ain't done yet.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (BLEARILY)
dialogues.text: That ain't my name. Dutch gets off his horse, helps Callaghan to his feet.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You alright? Callaghan nods. Dutch thinks, turns to Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: The horses need water, we need sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: The sun’s setting on John Clay's grave, and his killer’s still walking. We keep riding.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: The sun’s already set. We each sleep an hour and watch one. Then back on the trail.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Get back on your damn horses. Dutch starts unpacking his blankets from his saddle. Parc raises his eyebrows and looks at Callaghan. Callaghan shr and starts unpacking his own blankets. Parcher gets off his horse, pissed.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Callaghan's already asleep. Parcher and Dutch sit by the fire. Dutch drinks coffee. Parcher stews.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You cross me again, you and Walnut both can go to hell. I'd rather do this alone than with a couple old ladies. Dutch nods. Beat. Parcher spits, then SIGHS.  69.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Hard to fathom John Clay being dead. Known that man since we were little boys.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: -.-You’ve gotten people back before? Women. From the Indians. Parcher looks at him, sees how worried Dutch is.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Not personally, not alive. But I met a woman that come back. She weren’t never the same, but she lived.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We'll find her. Dutch looks into the fire. Another moment's silence.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'll take first watch. Parcher nods, then GROANS as he gets up and crosses to hi blankets. Dutch holds his rifle across his knees, drinkin coffee and looking out across the plains.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch shakes Parcher's shoulder. He jerks violently awake gets a hand on his revolver before he recognizes Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Jesus. Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Parcher, it's your watch.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I ain't been asleep two seconds.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: An hour. More. I need sleep.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: God damnit. Parcher GROANS, sits up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PALE SHAPES move in inky darkness. RATTLES, PURRING.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch opens his eyes, sees the campfire blazing unusually high. Callaghan’s blankets are empty. He rolls away from the fire, and sees Parcher’s blankets empty. He’s all alo Dutch sits up fast. He looks around. The camp is complete empty. He grabs his pistol, gets to his feet. The harsh glare of firelight reveals a circle of grass, b obscures the moonlit ocean of movement beyond.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Callaghan. Parcher. Dutch squints into the darkness. He takes a step out towa the grass and stops. Over the CRACKLING of the fire the nighttime sounds seem amplified, SHIFTING in the grass. A moment of uncertainty We see him from a distance, standing vulnerable in a circ of firelight, surrounded by infinite darkness. GURGLING RATTLES slide through darkness. He tightens his grip on his pistol. FOOTSTEPS in the grass behind him. Dutch spins. A FIGURE approaching.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Dutch. I can’t find Parcher. The figure resolves into Callaghan. Relief sweeps over Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: ...Why’s the fire so big?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I woke up from the heat of it and Parcher was already gone. Something’s up. Callaghan shakes his head. Dutch rubs the sleep out of hi face. He looks around. It hits him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He's... using us. The Indians see our fire, attack us. Parcher sees the Indians.  71.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: +..Son of a bitch. They stand for a moment, looking out into the darkness. T Callaghan starts kicking wood away from the fire.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Spread it out, we'll let it die down . Dutch kicks from the other side. The fire's quickly lower Dutch and Callaghan left standing over scattered, burning logs. A beat.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Is there more coffee? Callaghan shakes his head, no. The insect-like PURRING that's been rattling off the planes SWELLS.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Do you hear that? Dutch frowns, straining to listen. The PURRING builds and drops, hard to distinguish from the swaying of the grass.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: It's almost like... His voice trails off. Dutch listens. A beat. Parcher SCREAMS, off-screen. Dutch and Callaghan's heads snap to the sound. Dutch is the first to move, he grabs a burning piece of w and charges into the grass towards the sound of Parcher's voice, into the darkness. The RATTLING gets louder. On the edge of Dutch's vision, three figures are crouched the ground. Dutch throws his torch. It arcs end-over-end, sailing through the air, and lands the midst of the three. A HISSING SCREAM. The shower of sparks and muted flame reveals- TWO BURROWERS crouched over Parcher. The brief light give a glimpse of the creatures, somewhere between a molting beetle and a drowned child. But only a glimpse. Dutch raises his rifle.  72. The Burrowers, out of the torch's light, nearly invisible slither like melted wax over the soil. CRACK, CRACK, Dutc fires his rifle at the creatures. CRACK, CRACK- THUNK, THUNK, bullets strike the creatures without effect They wiggle into the dirt, and in a matter of seconds, va down into it. Dutch looks at the moonlit grass, collapsing in CIRCULAR INDENTATIONS where the Burrowers dug down. (Just like the indentations they’ve found on the trail.)

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What... what... Dutch is on the edge of losing his shit.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: My neck. Dutch looks down. Parcher has a half-inch deep, seven-inc long TRENCH carved into his neck.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN PLAINS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Callaghan searches through the saddlebags. Dutch is standing, looking out at the plains. The PURRING RATTLE i all around them. Parcher sits by the fire, gingerly touch the wound on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Do we have bandages?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: It ain't bleeding. I can't even feel it. Parcher presses the palm of his hand against the wound, t takes his hand way and looks at it.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Jesus. Now I can't feel my hand. What did that Indian do?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Those weren't Indians. Callaghan pulls a bottle of whiskey and a canteen of wate from the saddlebags, and throws them to Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Here, clean it out.  73. Parcher ignores the water, takes a drink of whiskey. Callaghan spits, mutters-—

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: ...what right you had to stake us out like pieces of bait.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm the one who's god-damn cut. Dutch even got a look at ‘em.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Those weren't Indians. Dutch crosses to the fire, adds a handful of dead grass. fire FLARES and in the light they can see the grass movin around their camp. RATTLES, HISSES. Some of the grass see to move against the wind. The GURGLES and PURRING comes from all directions.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: They're all around us.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SLURRED)
dialogues.text: I can't feel my face.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I think... they're waiting for us to go back to sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Fat god-damn chance of that.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. PLAINS CAMP-
dialogues.text: The campfire blazes, casting a flickering orange light ov the plains. The three sit in a circle with their backs to the fire; each holds a gun and watches the plains. The side of Parcher's face above the wound is starting to droop like a stroke victim's. They don’t look at one another, but stare out at the grass as they talk.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Can't feel my tongue. Or much of my arm. I'm numb but I itch all over. ...I don't want to die like this, not by pieces.  74.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't think it'll kill you. That woman we sent back with Dobie, she was still alive.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (CHUCKLING)
dialogues.text: There's cold comfort. Parcher is still excited, adrenaline giving a shine to hi eyes behind his slightly slackened face. Dutch looks at h bewildered that he could find some strange pleasure in th Dutch considers, then-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What about Dobie? Parcher looks up, sobering slightly.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He could be out there alone with those...

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: He must be at the fort by now. (a beat, ) «+-You still got that cross?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Yes... Dutch fishes it out of his shirt and tosses it to Parcher Parcher can't catch it with his numb arm, has to fish aro in the dirt. He picks it up and MURMURS a quick prayer, kisses the cross.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Can I get some of that?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ..-Amen. Parcher kisses the cross again and tosses it awkwardly to Callaghan. Callaghan lunges, catches. He kisses it and MURMURS a prayer. Parcher feels the moist groove in his n

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (TO DUTCH)
dialogues.text: Here, man. Callaghan tosses the cross and Dutch catches it.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Keep it.  75.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: What, you don't believe? Dutch shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Then you need it more than I do.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: God-damned Indian must have poisoned the knife. Dutch pockets the cross.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: They been alone in this country maybe a thousand years. God knows what devilment they could of thought of in that time.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't think it was an Indian that cut you.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Looked like men but weren't. Sneaked up and cut a white man's throat in the night. Sounds Indian to me. They fall silent. The RATTLING and PURRS continue out in swaying grass, still strangely SOOTHING. Dutch looks at Parcher’s wound. Parcher beats his fist against the groun

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Whole... damn... arms is numb.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Your wound is the same as the Williams’ dead. Parcher looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Whoever did that is who took Maryanne. Took the Stewarts. We must be close. Can you ride? Parcher nods, struggles awkwardly to his feet.  76.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shit. Alright let's go. You don't get me on a horse soon, I won't be able to get on at all.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: They ride in a line, Dutch at the lead, followed by Parch and Callaghan. All have drawn guns. The BURROWER NOISES continue from the surrounding plains. The sky is enormous, filled with stars. Parcher's lip han limp, his eyes heavily lidded. Dutch rides slowly at the lead, watching the grass.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS
dialogues.text: They climb a rise in the land. Dutch is nodding on his horse, exhausted. Parcher spurs his own horse forward, alongside the lead.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It's almost light.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Maybe. I'm falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You'll be alright.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...-If I don't make it back, give that cross to Ms. Gertrude Spacks for me. Or give it to Dobie, tell him it's for his mother.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I’1l do it.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I appreciate it.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: A fire. Dutch looks over, Parcher swings his head over drunkenly. Callaghan points at a dot of orange light on the horizon.  77.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three riders approach FAITH, an attractive, 19-year-o Sioux woman sitting alone by a small fire with her rifle. She watches them steadily with dark, exhausted eyes. Parc calls out, his words drunken through his slackened face.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SIOUX, SUB-TITLED)
dialogues.text: <Friendly. Peaceful.> Faith looks at Parcher. Her eyes darken. She traces a finger on her own neck, mirroring Parcher's wound-

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <You are marked. Burrowers.> Parcher looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: What'd she say?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ---Told us to set a spell.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. FAITHS' CAMP- DAWN
dialogues.text: Faith's face slightly underlit by the dying embers.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Faithful.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Her name's Faith. Parcher, Dutch, and Callaghan sit around the dying fire. Parcher translates with an increasingly bleary voice.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <Burrowers killed my family. Last night I shot my husband so he would not have to suffer the feeding.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: She's talking about the Burrowers. Says they killed her family.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Ask her what a Burrower is.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Burrower. What tribe?> Faith doesn't even look at him.  78.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <They come every third generation. We tried to escape to the East, past the Great River. We were eight .>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <Burrower. What is it?> Faith looks at him. She seems tired and angry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- DAWN
dialogues.text: We fly over empty plains, grasslands extending forever.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: <They were here before white people, before humans even. They feed on buffalo.> We overcome a herd of BUFFALO, hundreds of them stampedin

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: A lone BUFFALO collapses in a heap on the plains. In the moonlight, a Burrower slithers onto the Buffalo's and RETCHES. It's indiscernible as a pale shadow. Eight Burrowers, just vague shapes in the darkness, roll Buffalo into an open pit.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: <They bury food, let it rot. The poisoned cannot sleep.>

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dobie's blue eye stares out of the soil. The ground bulge weakly over his wiggling finger.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They use some kind of poison, bury their food alive. Particles of dirt have collected in the moisture on the surface of Dobie's horribly bloodshot eye. A line of tear traces down his cheek  79.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. DOBIE'S CAMP- DAY
dialogues.text: The mess wagon lays untouched in the clearing. FOUR BUZZA peck at Audrey's corpse, shriveled like a mummy. A buzzar tears her CLAVICLE free and flies away with it.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- DAY
dialogues.text: DUTCH'S DERBY blows by, and out into the grass.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: <When the blood is thick and the organs are soft, they return and eat. They drink.>

dialogues.speaker: EXT. PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Eight Burrowers, half-concealed by grass, surround and co the barely disinterred buffalo, mouths fastened onto it.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: They eat... soft parts.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FAITH'S CAMP- MORNING
dialogues.text: Parcher's voice smears clumsily through his numb face.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Soft parts? What does that mean? Parcher shakes his head, he doesn't know.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I like my soft parts. Shit.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <You killed the buffalo. So the Burrowers found other food.> Faith talks to the ground-

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We could not escape sleep. They took five of us. A baby without a breast to feed it died yesterday.> Faith looks at Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <You should die. The sooner you die, the less you will suffer.> Parcher doesn't translate this.  80.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <How kill Burrowers? Stop poison?> Faith shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <My father said the Ute had fought them. But the Ute are as wicked as white men, they will not help.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Ute Indians know how to kill them.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Does she know how to stop the poison? Parcher looks at Dutch, then turns to Faith. He points at the wound on his neck.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: <Heal? Make whole?> Faith nods.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <You can die.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ...The Ute might know.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Where do we find Utes?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: There’s probably Ute scouts riding the same route we’re on, though they avoid the trails. We can find ‘em a day’s ride North. There’s a trading post, the Watangwa. If we can make it there...

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (INTERRUPTING)
dialogues.text: What about the Stewarts?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: What about them?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We can’t stop searching so you can go after your cure.  81.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We find the Utes, they lead us to the Burrower Tribe. We kill the Burrowers, you get your girl, go build that cabin on the prairie, play American. Dutch thinks, not sure to trust Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Is Faith coming with us?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Yeah. That or I'm shooting her. Parcher smiles at her. She knows better than to smile bac

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch watches the landscape roll under his horse. Faith walks along beside the three horses. Parcher has lashed h limp left hand to his saddle horn with a cord. He’s grinn excited like a kid on an Easter-egg hunt. Callaghan looks over at Faith, sees that she is beginning limp, as if afflicted with blisters. Dutch looks at Parcher, is a little disturbed by the fier not-quite-grin on his face, twisted by his slack muscles. There's a DARK SPOT on his jaw, like a BED SORE. Parcher turns his grin on Dutch, who looks away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS- DAY
dialogues.text: Trees again dot the plains. The land rises and falls in gentle swells. Stone domes poke through the ground. Dutch watches Parcher up ahead. A SCARLET BRUISE, like a blemish on rotting fruit, marks the back of Parcher's nec There's a sheen of yellow around it, maybe liquid. Faith is now riding behind Callaghan, asleep against his back. Callaghan veers his horse over towards Dutch's. Parcher is a short distance ahead, out of earshot.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You see that bruise on Parcher's neck?  82.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (NODDING)
dialogues.text: On his face and hands, too.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: He's falling apart.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: The Ute Indians will fix him.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You believe that? Dutch doesn’t answer. Callaghan slick and

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I'm thinking maybe I ain't so eager to risk my hide for that crazy old shitbird's Indian cure.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: We’re not risking anything for him.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You still think you’re gonna find your girl? That Maryanne Stewart? What if that’s happening to her? nods towards Parcher. Dutch looks at the sores, purple-yellow.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (O.S., INTERRUPTING)
dialogues.text: What's the ruckus back here? Parcher has slowed his horse, swerves over to join them.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Thought I mighta heard my name.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Just talking.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You boys look bushed. We're already in Ute territory. Couple hours shy of the Watangwa. Parcher spits. His voice comes out in a drunken slur.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I didn't sleep a wink last night. Just lay there with my gun, waiting for something to move. (MORE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: PARCHER (cont'd) Whatever them Indians cut me with, it's got my brain racing like a... like I was a young man again. I feel lucky. Makes me wish I could move my god-damn arms. Parcher LAUGHS. It's maudlin in his stroke-victim slur. Dutch and Callaghan exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Your wound is spotted.> Callaghan starts. Nobody realized she was awake. She nods the wound on Parcher's neck. The wound is marked with tin white fungal dots.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <That's how they will find you.> The grin vanishes from Parcher's slackened face.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: What was that?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: ..-Not a thing.

dialogues.speaker: BLACK ON SCREEN
dialogues.text: RATTLES, HISSES, the Burrower PURRING. Pale movement in darkness, like white worms in black soil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three horses and four riders approach a tall POLE dri into the ground, rags and feathers hanging from the top.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We're here. Dutch and Callaghan stop their horses. The pole seems to mark the dead center of nowhere. Rocky, forested hills ri up around them. The place looks like desolation, like people have died he from ambush, starvation, or both.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: The Watangwa. We made it.  84.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Made it? There’s no “here” here. We’re dead center nowhere. They’re completely alone, exposed, lost in the sparse tre

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: The Utes’1l come. We just gotta wait. Get me off this horse, my ass feels like soggy bread.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We shouldn’t stop.> Dutch gets off of his horse and looks around. Callaghan climbs off his horse nervously. Faith looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: No... <Don’t stop. It’s getting dark.> Callaghan looks at her, trying to understand. Faith is exhausted, gestures weakly as she speaks.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <They’11 kill us.> Callaghan imitates her speech, trying to communicate.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (PARROTING)
dialogues.text: <They’1l... kill...?>

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <They’11 kill us all.> This time he gets it right, no idea what he’s saying-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: <They’11 kill us all.>

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Your watch, man, I need sleep. Dutch blearily opens his eyes. Callaghan is crouching ove him, speaking low enough so only Dutch can hear.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: The old man's still awake. Dutch nods, and sits up from his blankets.  85.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS CAMP- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch sits by the campfire with a rifle across his knees, watching the plains. The RATTLING is soft, but it's there Dutch looks absolutely exhausted.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (SLURRED)
dialogues.text: Your eyes open, bud? Parcher is lying on his back by the fire, heavy-lidded ey staring upwards. The BRUISING on Parcher's face is worse, spreading nearly to his left eye. His left hand is nearly black. He's rotting alive.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Dutch. You hear me, Dutch?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'm awake.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Real good. You stay that way.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I'll tell you if I fall asleep.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Much appreciated. Dutch throws another piece of wood onto the fire.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You think that boy and his squaw are gonna try to leave us?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I'd sure hate to have to shoot somebody for trying to abandon me out here. Dutch stirs the fire. With each SWELL in the BURROWER RATTLE, Dutch's eyelids are tugged downward.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You hear what I'm saying?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: No, I'm asleep.  86. Parcher grins with the half of his mouth he can move. The PURRING from out in the grass swells, Dutch's eyes go a little glassy. Dutch yawns. Parcher grins. The Burrower PURRING swells again, tugging at Dutch's consciousness. Dutch lets his l droop downward. A beat. The CLICK of a cocked his pistol. Dutch's eyes snap open- Parcher is turned, watching the grass on the edge of camp behind them. It MOVES against the wind, in time with the Burrower RATTLING. Parcher's revolver weaves drunkenly at the movement. Dutch raises his rifle. The two gun barrels track the grass' movement, slowly acr the circumference of camp. Neither Parcher nor Dutch noti behind them- A PALE FIGURE rising from the earth on the far side of ca between Callaghan and Faith. The RATTLING grows. The grass moving before Dutch and Parcher pauses, then cu back the way it came. Stalks of grass collapse. Background, out of focus- The Burrower stalking Callaghan arrives over him, and draws back a clawed hand. Loose ear falls from its back and PATTERS softly on the ground. Dutch's eyes dart back at the sound. He YELLS and spins, raising the rifle. Callaghan opens his eyes and SCREAMS. CRACK, CRACK, Dutch fires. The second bullet hits the Burrower and it HISSES, retreating into the grass. The grass behind Parcher and Dutch collapses, and a SECON BURROWER emerges, slinking swiftly towards Dutch. Callaghan scrambles to his feet, likewise Faith. BLAM, Parcher fires his pistol limply into the earth, nea throwing the gun from his rotting hand. Dutch turns at th sound and finds- A GAPING MAW. A toothless mouth as big around as a baby's head, strung with mucous and bile, like a hole punched in sheet of melted cheese. The Burrower's head is mottled yellow and brown flesh, th eyes tiny, subterranean pink, too far apart. The flesh is plated, but soft, like a boiled insect.  87. Dutch throws himself backwards, towards the fire, CRACK, CRACK, firing his rifle into the creature. It jerks backwards, HISSING. Callaghan grabs his pistol off the ground. Faith scramble towards the fire. Parcher turns drunkenly towards Callaghan and raises his pistol. Movement in the grass behind Callaghan. Dutch fires, CRACK, CRACK, into the Burrower before him a insinuates itself into the earth and vanishes. BLAM, BLAM, Parcher fires his pistol at the Burrower behi Callaghan. BLAM, on Parcher's third shot, Callaghan YELLS and drops, holding his leg. Faith grabs the dropped pistol. Sudden silence but for Callaghan's PAINED BREATHING and t dwindling PURR of the retreating Burrowers.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Callaghan. Dutch runs to him. He pulls his belt tight around Callaghan's leg, staunching the flow of blood.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Did you see those things? Jesus Christ. Parcher is glassy-eyed excited, gun in hand, barely able prop himself up. He's almost laughing.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You shot me, goddamnit. Dutch struggles to tie off the impromptu tourniquet, his hands slick with blood. Callaghan HISSES in pain.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: I saved your life, boy. Callaghan holds his bleeding leg and stares at Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <Put more wood on the fire.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Put wood on the fire, she says.  88. Dutch picks up his rifle in one hand and uses the other t toss more wood on the fire. The firelight jumps, but does little to penetrate the forested hills.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We should go. We should keep moving. They’ll find him by his wound.> She points at Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We leave him, he’s already dead. We need to go.> Dutch looks at Faith, shakes his head-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don’t understand.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We must go. We keep moving or we die.>

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (TO PARCHER)
dialogues.text: What’s she saying?

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Nonsense. The squaw’s hysterical. Dutch shakes his head. He takes Faith’s hands and lifts them. He gestures.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Use hands. Sign.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Oh great Christ. Dutch ignores him. Faith gestures to Callaghan, Dutch, an the horses, then makes a moving gesture, thrusting a hand back out of the trees.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: She wants us to go. Callaghan, Parcher, and Faith are all looking at Dutch. H decision is going to determine their course.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What do you think?  89.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: No! You’re not gonna listen to that red-skinned bitch! Dutch looks at Parcher, makes his decision.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: She knows more than we do. (to Callaghan) Can you ride?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I don't know. If you get me ona horse, yeah, maybe.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Like hell. Parcher dumps the spent cartridges from his gun. He shove fresh round into one the five chambers. Dutch starts towards him. Parcher shuts the breach and raises the pistol. Dutch stops.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: We're staying right god-damn here. Dutch looks at him, he’s only six steps away, and Parcher barely able to lift the pistol. He steps forward. Parcher pulls the trigger. CLICK. Dutch lunges forward. Parcher pulls the trigger, CLICK. And again... Dutch yanks the gun out of his hand before the hammer can fall. Parcher flails his arm and YELLS like a toddler ina tantrum. (Like a half-paralyzed, rotting toddler in a tantrum.) He catches his breath, then-

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: God damn you to hell, Dutch.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The four riders lope along in a line. Faith behind Callag at the lead, nearly holding him in the saddle. Parcher slumped on his horse, hands tied at the wrist to the pomm Dutch brings up the rear, weary. Their horses pick their way slowly through the darkness. Callaghan sweats, grimacing with each bounce of his horse Dutch watches the moonlit landscape, silvery and dim.  90.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: You boys better hope to God I die. Nobody answers.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <More blood is coming.> She says it to Callaghan, gesturing to his leg. Blood is dribbling off the heel of his boot. He's near the point o falling unconscious. He pauses, calls out-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: ...Dutch. We gotta do something about my leg. He reins his horse to a halt. Ahead, Parcher grins throug his stroke-victim face.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS GULCH- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch adjusts the flame on a second lantern, the two smal fires together casting an ellipse of weak light. He leaves his rifle by the lanterns, stands, and crosses Callaghan's horse, which Faith holds by the reigns.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Here. Dutch reaches up and helps Callaghan off the horse. Callaghan leans heavily on Dutch's shoulders, grimacing a hissing with pain. He YELLS when his left leg touches ground. His right leg hangs limp, soaked with blood. Parcher watches, almost amused. Then he looks past them, into the darkness. Suddenly, yelled from outside the firelight-

dialogues.speaker: UTE VOICE, (O.S., YELLING)
dialogues.text: Good Indian! Peaceful! Good Indian! All eyes snap towards the sound. Dutch looks at his rifle. It's ten feet away, by the lanterns; he can't grab it without dropping Callaghan. TWO UTE WARRIORS walk into the circle of lantern light. O is Tall, the other Short. The short one points at himself  91.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: Good Indian. (Ute, s.t.) <Are you able to speak?> Nobody responds. Both Ute are armed with RIFLES slung aro their backs. The Shorter Ute has three BEARTRAPS on his b

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: No English. Dutch looks towards his rifle, then back at the Ute.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: Drop me. Get the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH, (SIOUX, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Ute.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Praise God, He sent us some Utes. I don't know any Ute words.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: Frangais?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (FRENCH, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Yes. I speak French.>

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE, (FRENCH, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Good. To speak French. We... good Indian. Friends.>

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: <We look for a missing white family. Burrowers took them.> The Tall Ute leans down and MURMURS something to the Shor one. He nods towards Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (WHISPERING)
dialogues.text: Get your rifle.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (LOW, TO CALLAGHAN)
dialogues.text: Can you stand?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Drop me. The Short Ute addresses Dutch again, pointing at Parcher.  92.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: <Dead man. We are to fix. Little fish? We come from south. We hunt. Little fish to hunt with.>

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He says they can fix you. Something about a small fish. <I don't understand.> The Tall Ute is moving towards Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Stay back! Tell him to stay back! The Short Ute shows his palms, trying to calm Parcher. Th Tall Ute keeps advancing. He pulls a bundle of TROPHIES f his belt, hanging on a loop of rawhide. They are trinkets jewelry, snatches of cloth.

dialogues.speaker: TALL UTE
dialogues.text: <Little fish. We use the sick as Little fish, understand?> He shakes the bundle of trophies.

dialogues.speaker: TALL UTE
dialogues.text: <From the sick.>

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He keeps saying Little Fish.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (REALIZING)
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ amighty. He's talking about bait.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Drop me. The Tall Ute reaches up and grabs the ropes binding Parch wrists to the saddle. Dutch drops Callaghan and dives for his rifle. Callaghan CRIES OUT in pain. Parcher gives a slurred YELL as he's yanked off the horse onto the ground, the Tall Ute holding him. Parcher flails the Tall Ute, knocking the hoop of trophies from his hand The trophies fall to the ground.  93. Dutch gets a hand around his rifle when BLAM, the earth i kicked up two feet from him. Faith SCREAMS. The Short Ute is pointing his rifle at him.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: <To take the Little Fish. We fix.> Dutch stays frozen over his rifle. Callaghan half-lies on the ground, holding his bleeding leg.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Shoot this son of a bitch! Pick up your god-damned rifle and shoot this son of a bitch! "Shoo zis sunuvabish" is how the words come out, slurred almost beyond understanding by now. The Short Ute holds h rifle on them as the Tall Ute drags Parcher across camp a past him, into the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: <Little Fish already dead. Little Fish for trap. To kill.>

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER, (OVERLAPPING)
dialogues.text: God damn you, Dutch! Don't let them take me! You killed me, you son of a bitch! Parcher and the Tall Ute are already out of the light of fire and out of sight. The Short Ute, holding the rifle o them, begins to back out of the firelight.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE
dialogues.text: <We are to fix. We are to kill.> The Short Ute backs into darkness and vanishes. Dutch stares into the darkness, the Short Ute could still just beyond the firelight, still pointing the rifle.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Are they gone?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't know. A beat. Dutch is the first to move. He crouches down and picks up the loop of trophies.

dialogues.speaker: FAITH
dialogues.text: <We leave. He is already dead. We leave now.>

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A dozen trinkets taken from dead settlers, belt buckles, jewelry, crosses. In between each trinket, there hangs a small grayish-white bone, like half of a child's jaw, toothless, non-human.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I hope you’re not thinking of going after him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: They said they could fix him. Or trap... Dutch falls silent, staring at the trinkets in his hand. mouth opens a little, tears shine in his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Oh god. In Dutch’s hand, hanging from the Ute’s trophy cord, is Maryanne Stewart’s BROOCH. Dutch leans against the horse closes his eyes. Callaghan watches him.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Dutch...? Dutch takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: She's dead. He stares off into the trees. Several moments- Dutch look on the edge of falling apart; exhausted, heart-broken. Callaghan waits to speak-

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Let’s go.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I have to go after Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Like hell you do. That sunuva bitch was dead ‘fore them Indians even touched him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It’s not for him. We don’t know how to heal the Burrowers poison. We don’t know to kill them.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: I want to go home.  95. We can see that Dutch wants to go home just as badly. He puts the brooch in his pocket. He takes a breath.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: They took Maryanne from her home. Home isn’t safe. Callaghan looks at him. Dutch holds his gaze. Callaghan, wearily, nods.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- EXT. NORTHERN HILLS GULCH- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch pulls Parcher's pistol from his saddle. Callaghan pushes himself painfully into a sitting positio against a saddle lying on the ground. Faith paces nearby, watching the edges of camp. She throws another piece of w on the fire. Dutch crosses to Callaghan and crouches.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: You be alright?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: No. You hurry back. I think she’ll watch out for me, but... Callaghan gestures towards Faith. Dutch stands, crosses t Faith, and hands her Parcher’s rifle.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Stay? Watch out for him. Dutch points at Callaghan. Tries to pantomime the sentenc Faith takes the rifle, and nods slightly.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN, (TO DUTCH)
dialogues.text: Be careful. Dutch takes up his own rifle and nods again. He looks frightened but determined. He takes a breath and walks aw from camp, out of the light of the fire.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The starlight shines somewhere between silver and lead, everything nearly black and white in the dim illumination It could be a daguerreotype. Luminous white-barked birch. Dutch moves through the trees cautiously, rifle in one ha and pistol in the other. He squints into the darkness.  96. WIND moves the small trees, shifting shadows dancing over blowing grass. Burrower RATTLES come and go from seemingl every direction.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE
dialogues.text: Dutch moves deeper into the trees. He seems to be moving towards and away from the Burrower RATTLE at the same tim RUNNING FOOTSTEPS crunch dead leaves. Dutch spins, just a The Short Ute arrives and CLOCKS Dutch across the face wi the butt of his rifle. Dutch drops his rifle and falls to the earth. The Short Ute lands on top of him, hand clampe over his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: SHORT UTE, (FRENCH, S.T.)
dialogues.text: <Silence.> CLICK, of a revolver being cocked. The Ute looks down. Dutch's revolver is pointed at his chest. BLAM. The Ute falls backwards, dead before he hits the ground. Dutch scrambles to his feet. The Ute doesn't move. Silenc his smoking gun. He looks around. Nobody but the dead Ute Parcher MOANS from somewhere nearby. It's a low, weak sou nearly a death-rattle. Dutch turns and runs in a crouch towards the sound. He ke his head low, pistol and rifle ready. He jogs through sma trees, CRUNCHING through dead leaves, rises a hill and fi

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS CLEARING- NIGHT
dialogues.text: A bare expanse of rocky earth, surrounded by trees. Dutch passes a pile of SHARPENED POLES, 12-foot birch spe lying piled at the clearing's edge. In the center, Parcher is lying face-up on a slab of rock his arms and legs bound by ropes pegged to the ground. Burrower PURRS and RATTLES surround the clearing. Dutch moves cautiously out towards Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: Jesus, Dutch. Thank God. Dutch leans down over him and unties Parcher's good arm.  97.

dialogues.speaker: PARCHER
dialogues.text: They put something in me. Made me drink...

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Drink? What was it? Dutch reaches across to untie Parcher's rotten arm. Parch glances past Dutch and GASPS. Dutch follows Parcher's eyes, glancing over his shoulder. Parcher LURCHES upward and GRABS the pistol from Dutch's waist, pointing it at the TALL UTE suddenly behind Dutch. BLAM, Parcher FIRES the gun, inches from Dutch's face. Th muzzle flash SEARS across Dutch's eyes, he falls backward A bullet wound PUNCTURES the belly of the Tall Ute. DUTCH'S POV- Washed-out, overexposed, a RINGING in his ea Dutch stumbles backwards, holding his flash-blinded eyes. His left foot pushes through a pile of dead leaves and SN a BEAR TRAP springs up, biting his ankle. Dutch SCREAMS and falls to the ground. The Tall Ute is half crab-walking, half dragging himself away, bleeding heavily from the gut. Parcher holds the pistol on him blearily, his arm swaying. Dutch is close to shock, his POV bleached nearly white. The Ute, near the edge of the clearing, lets himself collapse, holding his belly. Parcher lets the pistol drop and lies back on the rock. Dutch wedges his fingers beneath the jaws of the bear tra He pulls, straining. The jaws begin to separate... then a fingernail tears and the trap SNAPS shut again.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH, (PAIN)
dialogues.text: shit! FROM ABOVE- The Ute lies bleeding near the clearing's edg Parcher lies tethered by three points to a rock. Dutch si struggling to free his leg from the bear trap. SIX INDENTATIONS appear in the rocky soil, churning. SIX BURROWERS emerge into the clearing. They slink like cats, moving on all fours.  98. They cast their heads towards the Ute, and Dutch, then fo in on Parcher and spiral in towards him. Parcher is the first to see them. He GASPS. Parcher weakly lifts the dropped gun and BLAM, fires once before the first two Burrowers are on him. Dutch looks up at the sound, just in time to see the othe four Burrowers FLING themselves onto Parcher. They fasten their gaping maws onto his body like piglets on a sow. Parcher opens his mouth to scream, but the only sound tha comes out is the dying WHEEZE of a broken bellows. The Burrowers arch their backs and suck, SLURPING the rotten organs from Parcher's body. A Burrower pulls its pale head away from the buffet, its dripping with blood and gore, as if fresh from a pie-eati contest. It swings its head towards Dutch. Dutch, still tethered by the bear trap, looks at the creature. It HISSES with a blood-and-mucous strung mouth. Dutch crabwalks backwards, away from the Burrower, pullin the trap's tethering chain nearly taught before he FREEZE He looks down at his left hand, a SECOND BEAR TRAP waits beneath a thin covering of leaves. The Burrower starts slinking towards him. The thick yello nails on it's three-fingered hands drip white venom. Dutch looks from the bear trap blocking his path to the approaching creature. It’s ten feet away. It tenses to pounce, HISSING, then FLINGS itself at Dutch. Dutch YELLS, and catches the Burrower's hand, the drippin talons inches from his neck. He twists, pushing the creat onto the SECOND BEAR TRAP. The trap SNAPS, CRUNCHING into the Burrower's side. The Burrower ARCHES and SCREACHES in pain. Dutch rolls away, and from the ground grabs a STICK, arm- length, about two inches around. He wedges it into the ja of the trap holding his ankle, and pries it apart. The trapped Burrower, arm's length from Dutch, LUNGES at swiping. Dutch YANKS his leg free and rolls away, the venomous claw missing him by inches.

dialogues.speaker: TALL UTE, (UTE, SUB-TITLED)
dialogues.text: <No!>

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch looks over. Another BURROWER is slinking towards th gut-shot Ute, talons dripping. The Ute cries out. Dutch LURCHES to his feet, his wounded ankle nearly givin out, and limps to intercept the creature before it reache the Ute. One of the Burrowers still feeding on Parcher suddenly li its head and HISSES. It stumbles back from Parcher, drunkenly, and then collapses to the ground. The other three Burrowers raise their bloody maws from Parcher's drained corpse and look over. The unconscious Burrower lies on the ground, sucking small, shallow breat like an asthmatic child. The Burrower bearing down on the wounded Ute weaves drunkenly, but is only paces away. PANTING with pain, Dut grabs a SHARPENED POLE from the pile on the ground. The Burrower raises back a claw, ready to swipe at the Ut Dutch lunges, PLUNGING the birch pole through the Burrowe torso and into the ground below. The creature SCREECHES. The bear-trap Burrower's eyes are closed, it pushes weakl against the ground. The three Burrowers over Parcher stumble away, drunkenly. The Burrower speared to the ground wearily lolls its head

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: +-.-You poisoned them. The Ute, breathing through clenched teeth, almost grins. One-by-one, the Burrowers collapse blearily to the ground unconscious. Barely standing, Dutch watches them fall. All six creatures lie unconscious, smeared with Parcher's dark blood, breathing shallowly. Dutch tries to catch his breath. Parcher's body is an empty husk, pale white and mummified His chest and belly collapsed like a sunken soufflé.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Heavenly god. The gut-shot Ute is weakly trying to CALL OUT. Standing over an unconscious Burrower, Dutch gets our fir real clear look at the creatures:  100. Humanoid. Three thick fingers on each hand ending in thic black, curled nails. A half-dozen small, vestigial, beetl looking TALONS, like Alaskan crab legs, line its torso beneath the arms. It has tiny, puckered eyes. Mucous-strung mouths as big around as softballs. Completely hairless. A soft exoskeleton, like a molting insect's, over mottled, rotte looking flesh, a stark contrast against the crimson stain their cheeks and chins. Gooey strings of Parcher's blood blow in and out of the things' mouths in time with their RASPING BREATH. The Tall Ute CALLS OUT to Dutch, barely more than a direc MOAN. Dutch looks over. The Tall Ute's tunic is nearly black with blood in the moonlight. The Ute points across the clearing. Dutch's gaze follows the Ute's hand to the pile of BIRCH SPEARS, the sharpened poles at the clearing's edge. Dutch picks one up. The Tall Ute nods, and points at the Burrower Dutch speared, pinning to the ground. Then he points at the other unconscious creatures, pantomiming thrusting spears into them. Dutch limps over to the nearest Burrower, holds the spear over it, and looks at the Ute. The Ute nods desperately. Dutch kicks the Burrower onto its back, raises the spear, PLUNGES it downward into the thing's chest. The Ute pumps his fist, pantomiming driving the stake dow deeper. Dutch twists the spear and pushes it through the Burrower, down several feet into the ground. The Burrower twists with the pressure and BILE dribbles f its mouth. The Ute looks towards the East, where the first gray ligh dawn is appearing. He turns back to Dutch and points at t other Burrowers. Dutch nods, limps over and grabs two more spears. He kicks the second Burrower onto its back and drives the stake through its chest and into the ground. He drives a stake into the third Burrower. The Ute nods, relieved, and collapses onto his back, PANT Dutch impales the fourth Burrower. The fifth, and the six  101. Dutch stands, the Burrowers are STILL BREATHING. Blood an mucous shakes on their lips with every exhale.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It didn't work. (French, s.t.) <It didn't work> The Ute doesn't look at him.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: <They're still alive.> The Ute doesn't respond. Dutch is exhausted and all fucked up, looks like he's about to cry. He walks over to Parcher. Parcher's corpse looks frail as a baby bird. Dutch crouches down and grabs Parcher's corpse from under the arms. He lifts him, and starts to drag him away. He pulls him back six or seven feet before Parcher's boot catches on a rock. Dutch pulls and Parcher's withered left arm TEARS OFF. Dutch falls onto his ass with the mummified limb in his hand. He YELLS and drops it, scrambles backwards, and comes to a rest sitting on the ground. Dutch sits there. He stares at the ground. He looks at the gut-shot Ute lying on the ground. Dutch looks back at the ground and sits. SUNLIGHT hits him. Dutch looks up. The first rays of dawn cresting the horizon. The ASTHMATIC WHEEZING quickens, becomes more urgent. The Burrowers are stirring, limbs moving over the ground. The sun climbs a little higher over the horizon. Light is now falling directly on the six creatures. They WHEEZE and HISS, there is a faint SIZZLING. One Burrower opens its maw and lets loose a high-pitched soun like a DOG WHISTLE. It raises its arms to the spear pinni it to the ground. The others come fully awake, HISSING and SCREAMING. Dutch watches. The Burrowers' skin pulls tight in the sunlight, STEAM rises off of it.  102. A Burrower digs at the ground, uselessly scratching at th earth. TINY BLISTERS appear on their yellowish flesh. A Burrower, SCREAMING, pulls at the stake pinning it to t ground, actually lifting itself off the earth. The gut-shot Ute watches with fierce satisfaction. Burrower skin SIZZLES and CRACKS in the sunlight. BILE bubbles up from their mouths. They STEAM and SCREAM, fles falls from their bodies in blistering scraps. The Burrowe writhe on the ground, their flesh burning away. Huge BLISTERS rise and break. Dutch watches as they SCREAM and fall to pieces. By the time it's done, the Burrowers’ corpses look like B CHILDREN staked to the earth. Dutch, bathed in sunlight, sitting on the ground between Parcher's corpse and Parcher's arm, wipes the tears from eyes with bloody hands.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS CAMP- DAWN
dialogues.text: Callaghan is sitting and Faith pacing where we left them. Dutch, holding the Ute's arm around his shoulder, stumble into camp. The Ute's feet barely drag on the ground, his whole torso dark with blood. He's pale, but conscious.

dialogues.speaker: TIME LAPSE- MORNING
dialogues.text: They have the Ute laid out on blankets, taking shallow breaths. Faith is gently tying strips of blanket around t still-seeping wound in his stomach. Callaghan and Dutch sit nearby. Dutch drinks coffee.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: It was sunlight. Burned them alive. The Ute poisoned them. Put something in Parcher that would make the Burrowers sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Parcher's dead? (Dutch nods.) I'll miss him.  103. It's not a convincing performance. A beat, then-

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't know what the poison was. Callaghan looks at the gut-shot Ute.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Can he talk?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't think so. ...If he dies we won't find the poison.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: Shit. Nothing's easy.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I can make it to Fort Bismark and back with a doctor in two days.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: You think he can live that long?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't know. What about you?

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: -..Get to it. The longer you wait the deader we get. And you better stay dead South. You miss that fort by a few miles, you'll be lost for days. Dutch nods with heavy eyes. He wants nothing but sleep.

dialogues.speaker: CALLAGHAN
dialogues.text: And if you gotta sleep, sleep in the day, you hear me?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I won’t sleep. Faith, her hands red with the Ute's blood, watches Dutch Callaghan. Callaghan reaches out a hand, Dutch takes it a they shake. Faith cradles the wounded Ute’s head in her lap. He blear tries to speak, but can’t. Faith is close to tears. The Ute weakly points at Callaghan and Dutch, then covers ears with his hands. Tears roll down his face. Faith cradles his head in her lap.  104.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The rising sun finds Dobie's blue eye, slightly clouded o staring up at the deep blue sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: POUNDING HOOVES. From morning to noon to night, Dutch pus his horse hard across the sparse plains, Clay’s horse galloping on a rope tied behind. He switches horses to ke up his speed, eyes raccooned with exhaustion.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: Dutch rides, exhausted, world tilting carnival around him Burrower RATTLES swell out of the grass around him. The s GOLD CRUCIFIX, marked with WHITE GROWTHS, bounces inside Dutch’s breast pocket. The grasslands are watching him.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- DAWN
dialogues.text: A red sun crests the horizon. ON THE GROUND- Dobie’s eye stares out over the plains. DOBIE’S POV- through the grass, Dobie sees a horse and ri approaching. UNDERGROUND- Dobie’s finger wiggles furiously. The rider is crossing Dobie’s sight diagonally. He gets close enough that we can see that it’s Dutch. We see hope Dobie’s unmoving eye. Underground, his finger wiggles desperately. ON DUTCH- He reins his horse to a stop forty feet from Do looking down at the grass. He grins a little bit and we s what got his attention-- Dutch’s HAT, suspended in the gr He swings down, grabs the hat, and jams it onto his head. ON THE GROUND- Dobie watches Dutch climb back on his hors and ride away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SOUTHERN PLAINS- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Dutch stands, waving his arms at a MILITARY TRAIN, a doze Bluecoat soldiers and a mess wagon marching Northward. TW RIDERS break away from the train and head towards him.  105.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ARMY BARRACKS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP on Dutch's face, exhausted but at least cleaned eating. He watches the OFFSCREEN SOLDIERS talk-

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I can't rightly say, sir. He says Will Parcher was killed, and another man named Clay.

dialogues.speaker: LIEUTENANT, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Does he know the tribe that attacked him?

dialogues.speaker: SOLDIER, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: No, sir. He's a foreigner, sir. Might be simple.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch sits on a wagon, his left ankle thickly bandaged. H cleaned up, in fresh clothes. A black DRIVER and a DOCTOR sits in the wagon behind them. Six BLUECOATS ride alongsi along with an OGLALA SCOUT. Dutch holds a cane across his lap and watches the prairie ahead of them, anxious to return to his friends-

dialogues.speaker: EXT. NORTHERN HILLS / MILITARY CAMP- DUSK
dialogues.text: Faith and the Tall Ute hang dead from an impromptu GALLOW The blood from his stomach wound tracing his legs show th the Tall Ute was still alive when they strung him up.
