Dozens of BLUECOATS mill around, setting up camp. Standing by the wagon, leaning on his cane, Dutch stares slack-jawed at Faith and the Tall Ute's corpses. His eyes shine with tears. Campfires burn all around him, throughout the trees, a pleasant glow in the quickly fading light.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Parcher's German! Hey, Parcher's German! Dutch turns, Henry Victor walks quickly and warmly toward him, rubbing his hands together with satisfaction.  106.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: My god, man. They told me you were here. I'm afraid you were too late for Will Parcher.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I know.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: What the hell’d them Indians do? We buried him proper, though. Man was wiser'n I gave him credit. Took four days and no small pain to get them Sioux to tell us what Parcher guessed right off. We've got scouts routing out the Ute to the North as we speak. Were able to clear just about every last one of them from this land. Reg'lar Indians: they could whoop to beat the band but can't fight for shit.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: Where's Callaghan?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Who, now?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: He was your cook. He was with...

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Walnut! He would have owed me his life if he had survived.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: Amputated his leg and he up and died on us. Man was delirious, halucinating, never really woke. Tears creep down Dutch's cheeks. Henry Victor's talking t himself, barely notices Dutch is there.

dialogues.speaker: HENRY VICTOR
dialogues.text: ‘Course we never did find them Stewarts. Doubt we ever will, were probably dead before we even started looking. I guess all we can really do is make sure it never happens again.  107. Dutch looks at the ground, crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dutch rides Parcher's horse away from a dozen BLUECOAT SOLDIERS riding South.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the settlement from out in the plains, alone ina world of grass. The houses are still unoccupied. We tilt down and reveal six SUNKEN PATCHES in the ground. They’re graves, recently robbed. If we look closely, we c see scraps of bone and withered skin in the grass. A piec of lace from one of the Stewart children’s nightgowns. They were buried less than a 1/4 mile from their homes.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SPACKS HOUSE- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch rides towards the large Victorian home. He eyes the approaching home with trepidation.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SPACKS HOUSE PORCH- DAY
dialogues.text: Gertrude, wiping her hands on her apron, opens the door a finds Dutch standing with his hat in hand. Dutch inhales begin speaking...

dialogues.speaker: INT. GERTRUDE'S PARLOR- DAY
dialogues.text: Dutch perches uncomfortably on a wing-back chair as Gertr WEEPS softly, sitting on the sofa opposite. This has been going on for some time. Dutch holds his hat his knees, moving his hands along the brim. The GOLD CRUCIFIX dangles by its chain from Gertrude's ha Gertrude gets control, wipes at her face with a kerchief.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Have you had lunch, Mr. Leijderova?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SPACKS HOUSE- AFTERNOON
dialogues.text: Dutch carries a picnic basket, walking next to Gertrude, carries a blanket. They walk towards the box elder tree where the earlier picnic took place.  108.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Dobie's still alive.

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I think so, too.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: It's not a thinking matter. A mother would know. My son will come back to me. The GOLD CRUCIFIX is looped around Gertrude's neck.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: Do you like pineapple?

dialogues.speaker: DUTCH
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: I think you will. Parcher loved pineapple. She pauses.

dialogues.speaker: GERTRUDE
dialogues.text: I’m sorry about Maryanne. (Dutch nods) Her poor family... I don't want to feel guilty. I think our duty is to live as well as we can. It gives reason to the sacrifices that men like Parcher and you made. A lot of Americans died so we could make a life here. It would be a sin if we didn't. They arrive in the shade of the Box Elder. Gertrude finge the gold cross. It’s still spotted with tiny WHITE GROWTH

dialogues.speaker: EXT. THE SOUTHERN PLAINS- NIGHT
dialogues.text: The grass moves in amber waves across the slowly sloping land. The cloudless sky casts clear, stark, starlight dow onto the plains. Dobie is pulled from the earth by a doze hungry hands. He’s still alive, still awake when the feed begins.
